summary: Actor Rick Dalton gained fame and fortune by starring in a 1950s television Western, but is now struggling to find meaningful work in a Hollywood that he doesn't recognize anymore. He spends most of his time drinking and palling around with Cliff Booth, his easygoing best friend and longtime stunt double. Rick also happens to live next door to Roman Polanski and Sharon Tate -- the filmmaker and budding actress whose futures will forever be altered by members of the Manson Family.

reviews.content: Simply marvelous! Tarantino's another great hit for sure. Love it every minute of it.
Great interesting characters, terrible story and movie overall.

J'ai détesté ce film. Tarantino est nostalgique d'une époque qu'il n'a pas connue et s'offre un film qui lui fait plaisir à lui, avec des acteurs excellents. Sauf qu'il nous laisse en dehors, l'histoire n'a ni queue ni tête, c'est totalement superficiel, gratuit. Les personnages ont l'épaisseur de ces poupées découpées dans du papier. Les hommes s'en sortent un peu mieux, mais les personnages féminins n'ont aucune épaisseur, les filles sont cruches et bien sûr sont de 30 ans plus jeunes que leurs homologues masculins (on voit bien que c'est un mec de 60 ans qui a fait le film). Pour finir, Tarantino joue à la fin sur un suspens glauque et dégueulasse au sujet de Sharon Tate, et cela se termine dans une apothéose de violence insoutenable... Non, Tarantino est auteur complètement surfait, et on ne me reprendra plus jamais à aller voir un de ces films.
Tarantino says this is his best movie, I disagree. That's one of his worst.

A real amazing movie which brings you the old skool classic vibes of Hollywood land. The movie from start to end is really amazing. It's not a thriller or anything, but an atmospheric movie which you can watch at home on holidays or like that. Still the climax scene was really thrilling which was outstanding. The acting performance of the star cast like Leo, Brad and Margot and all was as expected was really outstanding as well. Anyway a really amazing movie which is a must watch one I say💯
Such a classic.well written and acted. Worth your time. Watch it!

I thought this was a pleasant surprise. I expected a lot from Tarantino since he made two of my favorite movies, and I got a pretty decent movie. Yes, it's kind of confusing and all, but it had that Tarantino's spark I missed so much. Violence, comedy, drama, it had it all, I loved it. The story is really nice, and the acting was inpecable, especially from Leonardo DiCaprio, man, he nailed it, a very underrated performance. Brad Pitt was good too and also the rest of the cast. Pretty good, I liked it.

This movie has all of the great things that make Tarantino's movies so great. The acting, dialogue, and story is really interesting. I am not going to spoil anything when I address a common complaint: What is the point? It is alternative history and how something as small as what happens can change historical narrative and history forever. It is a fascinating and great concept that just may be above the general watcher. The ending sequence is so amazingly coordinated and hilarious that you have to watch. I have re-watched this movie twice in a matter of weeks because I loved it so much. It becomes so engrossing that you forget how long the movie is, I was sad that it ended when it did because I absolutely wanted more.

Watch this film if you care about 1960's Hollywood. Watch if you want to view the dynamics concerning 1960's television actors and their stunt doubles. Watch if you know who Sharon Tate is. If you answered all three in the affirmative, than you're in the minority.

Once upon in Hollywood is an enjoyable if not slightly confusing watch. The lack of a real storyline both makes the film feel both feel spontaneous and random, yet almost documentary like, as if you are discovering what will happen next at the same time as the characters. Tate, played by Margot Robbie is a seemingly small and unexplored character within the film, yet her contrast with Di Caprio's character and their differing experiences of Hollywood make her an interesting asset to the movie none the less.  The ending scenes provide the most storyline the film is willing to give, but don't quite tie together the randomness of the preceeding hour of so of film. I don't believe this is necessarily a negative, as the characters, set and dialogue are compelling enough that the lack of a story never slips into the realms of being boring. In fact, the scenes of driving through 60s Los Angeles, along with Cliff Booth's undeniable cool factor and slick lines, make the film exciting and enjoyable even before the typical Tarrentino action ensues.
Incohesive and boring. Easily Tarantino's worst film in my opinion.

Unfortunately, the film has no "plot", but this is quickly made up for by the great acting of Brad Pitt and Leonardo Di Caprio and, of course, Margot Robbie. Almost more exciting than the plot of the film is the backstory of the film, the thoughts Quentin Tarantino had.

My favorite Tarantino film of all time. And I really love all his stuff, esp Jackie Brown.
I've seen it 7 times now, and each time I pick up new things. It just gets better! Pitt and Leo are phenomenal playing off each other

When Tarantino puts out a movie… it's an event that I am happy to lineup for. And I'm happy to say this one did not disappoint. When I say, which is my favorite Tarantino movie, it usually happens to be the one that I'm watching currently but after many viewings, (and I know this is an unpopular opinion) this might be my favorite Tarantino film. This one certainly had probably the most laughs I've had at a Tarantino film and it's stuck with me more each time that I watched it…when you go to the movies you want to be entertained and when you watch a Tarantino film, you know his primary goal is to take you into his movie world and give you an experience. The acting is phenomenal down to every single character. The dialogue is witty and smart, and the direction and photography along with the set design is sublime. And the best part is this really is a buddy film (  and you can feel the love between these two friends, Rick Dalton, and Cliff Booth.) Leo and Brad play them to perfection. Kudos that the Academy recognized Brad Pitt for his performance, but Leo was phenomenal as well and the direction and movie as a whole was just a blast. And it brought attention to an actress I really didn't know much about other than the Manson murders.  Margot Robbie was terrific as well in her portrayal of Sharon Tate . I certainly hope Tarantino is going to give us at least one more masterpiece before he hangs up his directors chair.

What a cracking film. Great dialogue, great acting. Tarantino on top form. Hugely enjoyable throughout. BUT. Give the back story of Charles Manson that runs through the entirety of the film there is a palpable sense that things are just not going to work out well. You feel uneasy. And then...
No seriously, watch this film.

Some characters fall flat and it can be a bit weakly paced at times, but as usual Tarantinoism- there is a very unconventionally told narrative filled with sick moments, beautifully shot scenes, immaculate screenplay and two outstanding performances from its two famed leads. A great movie, well acted with DiCaprio's portrayal of Hollywood star dealing with a faltering career, and his friend (and also struggling) stuntman played by Pitt.  Tarantino brings the Hollywood of the late 60s to life with depth, humanity and the sort of excellent dialogue we expect from him.  Margot Robbie's Sharon Tate brings a much-needed portrayal of the actress as a person rather than a victim.  The violent climax is over the top, sucking some of the energy out of a near-perfect movie, though it can't derail an ending that hits all the right notes beautifully.

The film itself as entertainment value was disappointing. Much of the first half was about an insecure actor filming western movies and they focused a lot of time on that filming. Then in comes the Manson clan. At about 1 hour 45 minutes in, I finally started to perk up as it tended to focus more on the real lives of the people it was about. At one point before that I was about to turn it off. The last 1-1/2 hours saved it from becoming a 1-star movie. I think it would have been a better movie to leave out all the sad-actor western filming and just stick with one theme, one life story. . . Sharon Tate.

This is a movie I am positive will age like a fine wine.  I too was confused upon my first watch, and even my second.  However come 3rd watch I realized this is a masterpiece.  Leo is the best actor of our generation playing a mediocre and insecure actor who within the movie must play his characters with different acting prowess at different points. The story unfolds within 2 or 3 days but the characters are laid bare within what might be consider simple exchanges.  I personally think this is the Tarantino at the height of his powers.  Most will choose Pulp Fiction, I think this is his seminal work.

Rated R: for revisionist history fever dreams. Not suitable for IQ's over 100.
I seriously think Quinton has some deep psychological issue to keep writing this kind of revisionist crap. Does it make him feel better? It's just really, really weird. You usually don't see this kind of detachment from reality outside of a cartoon or superhero movie. For me it just doesn't work because I have a brain. I didn't cheer when the good guys killed the Nazis in Inglorious Bastards. I just found it completely stupid. Same with this horrible ending. Unless you are doing major world building then rewriting major historical events in isolation is just, really, really stupid and more then a little bit weird.
Outside of that there is pretty much zero plot here. Just following around a has been actor and his tough guy lap dog until the final fever dream at the end. 
It's DiCaprios worst performance in a while. The accent is just awful. 
Pitt does more with a single look than 100 lines from DiCaprio. But then Pitts sycophantic, tough guy character is not very believable. To be believable he would have had to punch DiCaprio's character right in the face several times because no self respecting person would endure DiCaprios constant sniveling.
Margot Robbie is in it but has so little screen time you'll forget all about her. Just seemed like a total waste of talent.
At least he resisted going to Spahn ranch and killing Charlie with a flame thrower in the end.

I enjoy a nostalgic setting and seeing how life was not that long ago. If you expect frenetic edits and multiple explosions per frame you will be disappointed. If you know what REALLY happened, you will instantly recognize the tension from the horror that is to come. It is enough to hold the viewer in anticipation -- they will wait patiently to see how Cliff Booth is going to tear apart the Manson thugs. My only beef with any QT film is that he stays in that revenge zone a bit too long. It feels good to repay evil with suffering. The questions is: how much can a good person punish evil, without himself becoming evil? One effective head bash is sufficient in most cases, but doing it over and over just makes the protagonist look like a fiend. Perhaps QT has been holding up that mirror to teach that fact. I feel good when I should feel shame.
Can't say I'm a fan of any of the actors but the spin on the Sharon Tate spin was nicely done, must admit. Watch it and enjoy just as a movie - it's nothing more than that.

Would be 3.5 but too much wasted time on "filler" scenes.

In general, Quentin Tarantino is overrated, and in this fashion he now got ahead of himself. Being in a better position than ever to cast who ever superstar he wants, he obviously does it, again, but only to smear them out on a too long and effectively tedious carouse through diverse Hollywood elements.  It's all like he's opening a number of luxury tin can food flavours to say: - Look what I can eat, and no surprise, it always ends in his signature, an orgy of violence. This is just not necessarily very impressing, if it ever was. Since Pulp Fiction, his great exception and perhaps best film is Inglourious Basterds, because there's actually a good intentional point behind it all.

Once Upon a Time…In Hollywood dishes out the best and worst of what Quentin Tarantino has to offer.  Centered around the relationship between fading actor Rick Dalton (Leonardo DiCaprio) and his stuntman Cliff Booth, the film is a nostalgic look at Hollywood culture during the summer of 1969.  On the positive side, the characters are relentlessly interesting, the story is original, the acting is great, the dialogue is fantastic, the soundtrack is spot on, and Tarantino's visual style (lots of effective tracking shots, crane shots, etc) is evident at all times.  The primary negative issue is the bloated 159 minute running time, thanks to Tarantino's inclusion of scenes that are either too long or totally unnecessary and the ridiculous number of cutaway shots of the cultural detritus of the time, giving the impression that he is more interested in entertaining himself than he is in entertaining the audience.  It's good, but it should have been great.

The characters / acting and numerous odes to the Golden Age of Hollywood keep this movie engaging. And just as you wonder where it's going, everything comes together and concludes in classic Tarantino style.

If you've got three very long hours to carve out, "Once Upon a Time...in Hollywood" is a fun wallow through Tarantino's alt-history of the Manson murders, together with a nostalgic look at 60s Tinsletown. Tarantino's most accessible flick, it's a must-see for history buffs and cinephiles, but watch it on video to pause for yawns and a ninth inning stretch.

This Tarantino magic is truly unique; like nothing else in the film industry. It takes a deep journey into the lives of two men looking for their place of fame in Hollywood; all masterfully complimented with outstanding filming, talented acting, and a mind-blowing production set that deserves in full the awards it has received due to its time period accuracy. Being set in the late 1960s, there is no 21st century vibe throughout the whole film which fully impresses me. A lot goes on during the film and requires full attention and concentration. Multiple viewings is also advised. Quentin Tarantino applies a genius twist to a true story, thus resulting in this thrilling masterpiece.

Arguably Tarantino's most restrained picture may also be his most tedious, at least as far as wide audience appeal is concerned. Not only is this is a fairly slow paced movie, it is a film where one certainly feels its legnth. The majority of the film is split between Leo DiCaprio's pitiable Rick Dalton, a former movie and tv cowboy star, now washed up and looking for a second wind; and his best friend/stuntman/chauffeur Cliff Booth, played by the always charismatic Brad Pitt. Together they go about their day-to-day lives in 1969 Hollywood, and really thats about it. The film masterfully plays with audiences expectations, especially those familiar with certain tragic events set to take place one fateful night in August involving Rick's neighbor, Sharon Tate, endearingly played by Margot Robbie. In Tarantino's Hollywood there is an ever-looming threat one cannot escape from, and not just from the hippies. One never truly feels safe, as though the ball could drop at any given moment, and Tarantino knows that we have come to expect this. So instead he builds up tension for 2 hours before pulling the figurative trigger and delivering exactly what we want.

I enjoyed this. It was a Tarantino film filled with his typical dialog and characters. But, when it was over, I must admit that I felt no need to see it again. It was entertaining, but not compelling.

the good: great acting (Leonardo DiCaprio is excellent), great directing, and the whole feel of the film is very pleasant and fresh which is not a surprise from the director.
the not so good: its very long and the underlying story feels weak, too weak for the length of the film.
summary - it was kind of "meh".

'Once Upon a Time in Hollywood' sounded like it would be a great film from the get go. Although Quentin Tarantino's films have been spotty in recent years, his best work such as 'Reservoir Dogs' and especially 'Pulp Fiction' are masterpieces. The cast consists of many immensely talented actors. It looked great from the advertising and who cannot help resist that title. That it was one of the year's most positively received films further added to the interest.

Although it is not quite perfect, 'Once Upon a Time in Hollywood' to me was as great as hoped. One of Tarantino's best in direction, writing and as a film as an overall whole in recent years, towards the better end of his filmography and one of 2019's best films, its positive reception richly deserved. It is unmistakable Tarantino in a good way and a great representation of the cast, with many giving some of their best work in recent years.

Will start with the very, very few things that didn't quite come off for my tastes. Some of the pace, especially for a film as long as it was, could have tightened and not every scene felt necessary. Actually would have trimmed some or all of Sharon Tate in the cinema, regardless of how beguiling the production values and Margot Robbie's (that smile is a beauty) acting were.

Did think too that the Bruce Lee caricature and encounter were quite tasteless and anybody who was offended can't be blamed.

That sounds like a film worth a 7 or 8 out of 10. The good things though were so amazing and the film was in a different league to a lot of films released this year that to me awarding 'Once Upon a Time in Hollywood' either of those scores felt too low. It looks wonderful, dazzlingly shot with shots filled to the brim with atmosphere, stylishly edited with a lovingly recreated period. Tarantino directs with great confidence and his distinctive style is all over it. The music is used sparingly, but the music choices are very effective when used. Particularly so the quite sinister use of "Twelve Thirty" in a scene that already makes one feel unnerved.

Script has the hard-boiled edge necessary and has entertainment and intensity. A word of warning, there is a lot of profanity (am mentioning this because this is something that bothers people) but to me it didn't feel as gratuitous as feared. Some pacing issues aside, the story is often absorbing and is quite nostalgic and daring with expert melding of fact and fiction. A few great scenes are everything to do with the making of the western with Rick and the girl (fans of classic-era westerns will enjoy it, likewise anybody with super fond memories of episodic television), Cliff's truly chilling encounter at the Spahn Movie Ranch and the splendidly over the top (and extremely violent just to warn you) finale in true Tarantino style.

Found the characters to be interesting, with Rick and Cliff being quite meaty roles. The acting is exemplary, Leonardo DiCaprio is charisma and intensity personified and Brad Pitt, here the epitome of cool, has not been this good in years. Margot Robbie is absolutely radiant with a smile that lights up the screen. Bruce Dern, Damian Lewis and Al Pacino provide delicious support in small roles.

In conclusion, the odd pacing issue and one tasteless scene aside this was a great film. 9/10
As a younger person coming in with only a bit of prior knowledge and background on this film and real life events. It had a certain magical taste at the end. Very good watch all round.

Its entertaining but to provide an alternative ending to the Sharon Tate killings is in bad taste. Does the Director get away with this because her husband Polanski is a fugitive from justice and hate figure in the USA? Tarantino also has a dig at Bruce Lee also deceased and unable to react. Easy targets.

This is such a terrible movie. Perhaps it is about time we use our brains and freedom of speech to say what we all know by now: Tarantino is a tired and overrated product of its time, the result of the collision of a traditional egomaniac and his fetishes with the turn of the century's pop culture. His formulaic characters, repetitive storytelling, disconcerting misogyny and limited stylistic choices have no place in the cultural entertainment landscape moving forwards.

One of Quentin Tarantino's lighter movies, the more character-driven Once Upon a Time in Hollywood has great dialogue, well-defined characters performed masterfully well be they real or fictitious, a memorably unsettling sequence at what is known as the Manson Ranch, amsuing sense of humour, wonderfully realised, immersive production values and one heck of an ending (if admittedly derivative of a past non-Western Tarantino period piece). It's not for everybody and the nearly-three-hour runtime will test the patience of viewers who aren't into Leonardo DiCaprio chatting with a precocious 8-year-old girl (well-written scene by the way) but, after the disappointment that was The Hateful Eight, what might be Quentin Tarantino's penultimate directorial effort proves, as far as people who still like his work are concerned, that the man's still got it.
Not Tarantino's best, but found it a thoroughly entertaining film.

Though advertised as an accurate biographical account of the Manson Murders in 1960s Hollywood, this film is actually more fictional, less about these murders and more a love letter to the actors of that time. The story is centred around director Roman Polanski and wife Sharon Tate's fictional neighbour, actor Rick Dalton and his stunt man Cliff Booth (based screen legends Steve McQueen and Burt Reynolds and the latter's stunt-double Hal Needham). The film explores how the two are struggling to adapt to the ever-changing Hollywood, paralleling with the growth of the Manson family who are interested with the Tate/Polanski household. Though a long film, it does quite well at showcasing the struggles of actors in Hollywood, the indulgence of the rich and the rise of a fanatic cult.
Instant classic. I loved it from start to finish

Sorted by efforts on screen in this disrespect for the victims of the Charles Manson murders in the 1960s: Brad Pitt, Leonardo Di Caprio, Dakota Fanning, Margot Robbie and in last place TARANTINO!!. 2/10

With a title like Once Upon A Time... In Hollywood, knowing of Tarantino's great passion for cinema, my expectations were high. For its three hours of running time, what we got is a sleepy bedtime story glued together with a bunch of mediocre sketches of dead celebrities not saying or revealing anything compelling. If you're still awake, you will be treated to another of Tarantino's over the top signature finales. You know...The total destruction of the bad guys. Dog mauling, flame thrower and all.
It's a strange one, as sometimes it feels like it doesn't have a point, and yet it's still interesting. Probably my favorite Tarantino movie. I don't like his stranger stuff.
fantastic film do not get me wrong but compared to Tarantinos other works it feels weak. There are great scenes here and there but often times just not much is going on.

What could've been another masterpiece in Tarantino's line up ends up suffering from some of the worst pacing I've ever seen and a lack of engaging storytelling. Once Upon a Time in Hollywood has one banger cast and two lovable leads, Leonardo DiCaprio, Brad Pitt, Margot Robbie, they all give it their all and it's one of this movie's redeeming qualities that saves it from being completely abysmal. The setting of 60's Hollywood is quite clever and allows our stars to pull off some wacky scenes. However, quirky characters and excellent chemistry can only get you so far, as the pacing is truly god awful, the first 3 quarters of this movie are slow as molasses with barely any plot development, and then once we actually get to the final act, it switches into its highest gear and blazes through it at the speed of light. Still, the final act of the movie is the best as it finally feels like something important is happening with even more funny interactions. Once Upon a Time in Hollywood has everything in place to deliver an exciting look-back on old school Hollywood, but would improve tenfold with a bit of an overhaul such as a new cut that trims down this slog of a movie.

A fun character study movie, but the plot and the end in particular felt like wishful thinking.

It strikes me as not the kind of movie a confident director would make, and Tarantino's own insecurities show through as a denial rather than a confession.

A darkly funny and entertaining picture, and surprising return to form for Tarantino. This is surely his best directed feature since Pulp Fiction. The performance from Leonardo DiCaprio is simply outstanding, particularly when he convincingly pulls off playing a man acting badly. The film is also directed with great class, with an excellent script that expertly blends real and fictitious history, with a great homage to the late Sharon Tate. Once Upon a Time in Hollywood manages to successfully recreate the Los Angeles landscape in a late 1960s setting, and do so in a way very pleasing to the eye.

That Tarantino uses unconventional narrative methods to tell unexpected stories is established. Hollywood is no exception as nothing much happens for the first four fifths of the movie. It is very watchable and enjoyable, with lovely performances by DiCaprio and Pitt. The central characters are revealed to the audience via a series of engaging vignettes. The last fifth is a fictionalized alternative version of the Manson family murders, with a far more satisfying conclusion than reality.

There's self-indulgence and there's gluttony. With some films you feel that they're perhaps 10 minutes too long. Here, there's a whole hour that could have been cut without losing anything. After all, there isn't much to lose when the entire film is made up of sub plots. Pretty much the whole of Dicaprio's role is pointless. Pitt, though, has fun and holds the film together with a casual swagger that suggests that something may come of the film. It doesn't, but while he's on screen, you don't mind so much

Esta película para mi representa todas esas películas que con el paso del tiempo se han dejado de hacer. Para mi el mayor acierto de esta película esta en hacer varias escenas que parecen que no tienen nada que ver entre si para que al final todas las conclusiones de las mini historias de la película se unan para crear un espectacular final que desde hace tiempo no veía un final tan perfecto, desde acción hasta dialogo movimiento de cámara. Otra cosa memorable de esta película son las muchas escenas en las que aparecen Leonardo DiCaprio y  Brad Pitt, que muchas por su increíble actuación se vuelven inolvidables, que la mayoría rayan en la perfección. para mi en lo único que falla la película es que en querer hacer una película que se centre en hacer una película de mini historias muchas veces se hace confuso y un poco aburrido. haciendo que sea una película que se disfrute mas viéndola una 2da vez, ya que sabes como va embonando cada historia para crear ese gran final. Para mi esta es una película con una historia solidad que se va perfeccionando en conforme avance. Muy recomendable.

It is a legendary director with veteran actors but it lived up to the hype. (I also want to personally thank my dad for constantly putting on Kill Bill when I was little and even though I got annoyed by the film and didn't appreciate cinema at that age, he exposed me to one of the greatest in the industry). Powerhouse performances and an ode to classical Hollywood that contains Brad Pitt driving around iconic landmarks from Arclight Cinemas to Chili Johns. The last 20 minutes of the film pays tribute to the store that's classic Tarantino (if you know, you know) and ones the credits role, one cannot help but say, "ah, the magic of Tarantino," once again.

Not by any means one of Tarantino's best, but still a pretty good film and very charming. I liked it a lot even though I feel the story was a little bit long and pointless. I mean, it works in the sense that the switch at the end is genuinely surprising. The movie's about twenty minutes too long and I really started to feel it by the end. Also, while I genuinely liked watching it once, I'm not sure I'd enjoy watching it again.

A nearly 3 hour film which takes far too long to really truly introduce the antagonists, and then what also feels too long before they begin... antagonizing, ultimately culminates in Tarantino's classic and excellent action for about 5 minutes to quickly wrap everything up.

In the grand scheme of Tarantino Movies, this one doesn't float my boat as well as the rest. Sure, there is a maturity to this film that shows growth, and there's no doubting that this is a movie that is probably more personal to QT than his other endeavours, but it's a difficult one to compare to the rest of his back catalogue.

It's certainly not gritty like Resevoir Dogs, or as cult as Pulp Fiction. It's not as comedic as Jackie Brown. Overall, it doesn't enthrall like these movies.

There are times when the film becomes too long in the tooth. Scenes showing the acting on set of Rick Dalton at times feel needless and add little to the storyline. It also feels TOO restrained at times and really only nods to QTs more gloriously over-dramatic style towards the last 20 minutes.

What is done well though is Quentin's ability to lead your thought process one way and then turn it around - or drop the idea dead. There are times when you think "yeah, this will lead to ..." Only to have there be no lead there at all.

Also done well is the usage of an all-star cast in bit parts without the appearances feeling like little Camo performances to bring a big name to a film. Again, truly a nod to the greatness of Tarantino in that he can bring in massive names for small parts and leave the audience fulfilled.

You have to watch this if you like to watch movies by Quentin Tarantino, but equally if you're a fan of any of the lead stars too. And if you're not, it's still a good film to watch.

But if you're looking for classic Tarantino with a lot of action and a storyline that makes you think hard - you're in for a bit of a shock.
Fun, enjoyable, and thrilling and satisfying ending

It's just a fun movie. A film dedicated to a timeline that never was, and that revels in the violence against the lunatics who in reality caused so much cruelty. It's escapism at its finest, and the path toward the films incredible ending is littered with a hundred fantastic moments.

Quentin Tarantino delivers this fantastic nostalgic trip down memory lane with once upon a time in Hollywood. The writing in the dialogue as well as the soundtrack within the film teleport you to 1969 Hollywood. As a kid, I would go to California every summer and the scenery in the film brought back so many memories. The set design of downtown Hollywood is so impressive you feel like you are really there. Not to mention, the fantastically brutal fight scene in the climax of the film.

The film adopts a nostalgic profile that is VERY well constructed, with maximum excellence. The crisis of identity and the way cinema works is the maximum point of Tarantino's personal touch in the film and certainly the best part of it.
Very cool movie. Tarantino is definitely one of the best.

Quentin Tarantino most pure nostalgia-hued Golden Age-Hollywood. Definitely Tarantino Love Letter to Hollywood. It has everything you want from Tarantino Amazing Soundtrack, Dialogue, Violence, etc. If you want to

The movie QT has been building to his entire career, it's a brilliant, wildly thrilling, completely original, and deeply resonant piece of storytelling that only a great pop artist can create after their voice has evolved over the course of 25 years. It's the best movie of the past decade, one of the best of this century, so far, and a sterling reminder of just how great, resonant, inspiring and unforgettable movies can be when the corporations just get out of the way and let a gifted artist do his thing when he's truly in tune with and channeling the desires and impulses that fuel his creativity. The cast is also perfect. The character of Cliff Booth is one of the best creations of recent memory. It's also the best use of Brad Pitt in a movie ever.
Loved it.  Brad Pitt alone but that finale scene…wow.  I put off watching it initially too due to runtime.  Honestly so worth it.

Não esperava esse final. Foi um surpresa boa. Além da história desenvolver todos os personagens, não é colocada de forma tão expositiva. Além de ter uma cinematográfia excelente e nos transportar para o ano que se passa o filme.
As of now, this is QT's weakest film. It is not cohesive enough nor does it tell a good enough story for most to become invested. The setting and costumes are highlights of the film.

While I have great respect for him, I can't watch all Tarantino movies due to the gore.  So this was do-able, and I found the flame-thrower pool scene near the end particularly gratifying.  
This boy's got Southern roots, and it comes out in his pacing, his humor, and his economy of words.  I'm good with all of that.  So much of what he does isn't even all that good, it's just weird - with great soundtracks and kitsch and casts and budgets.  And that's enough of a contrast to what we usually get, so I'm also good with that.  
It's a funny movie that I thoroughly enjoyed.  I was also a bit horrified at how well, and frequently, DiCaprio hocks loogies, and the dexterity with which he handles cigarettes, lighters, and the way he can hold and spew smoke on command almost like it's a dialogue unto itself.  It's literally physical comedy, loogies aside - that boy prob has a habit he doesn't need.  But gracious, he's good at it.  
There's almost a juvenile aspect to most Tarantino movies, that when added to big boy resources, just works.  I can enjoy some caricature.  And I don't understand why everyone else is derivative but him…..  I mean, I think everything at this point is largely derivative, I don't consider that a problem, just don't understand all the discrepancies in application.  
Maybe this is Tarantino for the masses, I dunno, but I thought it was delightful and got a lot of laughs and enjoyment from it.  Think you just need to kinda know what you're getting.  With proper expectations, this is funny as heck.

A sometimes tasteless, long and boring retelling of the Manson murders as a sort of comedy (with not many laughs) and of course with a radically different outcome. The amusing bits are the pastiches of old TV shows and films. The rest seems pointless - it is not particularly funny, insightful or anything else. Perhaps the worst product so far from this director who is hugely over-rated anyway. The sets, props and character appearances are of course momentarily diverting.
Bem complexo, uma filmagem bem interessante e complexa. Achei que é um estilo que vale a pena ver.

Some movies are so good they rate a re-watch, and if you're lucky, that re-watch reveals new layers & details you hadn't appreciated the first time around.  So I find it with "Once Upon a Time...".  First is the immaculately detailed and richly nostalgic look, sound, & feel of the late 60's; a decade that began with so much hope & promise, but which was starting to turn "bad" by 1969, even if a callow young college student like myself didn't recognize the shift happening at the time.  Next is the level of thought & creativity Tarantino put into the story line of the fictitious Western TV series "Bounty Law", that prefaces the decline of Rick Dalton's Hollywood career.  The movie puts enough "hooks" into this that I actually hope Tarantino does indulge his clearly well-thought out fantasy to make a real film or a pilot around "Bounty Law".  I for one would watch it!  Lastly, thanks Quentin for NOT running us through the real ending to the Sharon Tate story one more time.  I wish you could have written the "endings" for the whole damn decade.  We'd live in a much better world today if you could have!

More Tarantino garbage. Inane script and mind-numbingly boring scenes designed to force his love of '60s soundtrack on the audience. Bruce Lee scenes were farcical and disrespectful.

He's a poor man's Scorsese with a hard-on for gratuitous violence. Sometimes you wonder if he's actually got a screw loose or maybe he's just completely creatively bankrupt. A one-trick pony whose best days are long gone - shame he never matured as a director.
No scenes of tension. No question marks, no arc. Just filmed beautifully, without heart, soul or script. Humour not there. Ending was whacky.... Indulgent film making sucks

Classic QT: bombastic, retro-tacky hollywood kitsch with horrible dialogue. The aimless, yammering script is completely devoid of depth, subtlety or nuance. Brad and Leo were the perfect choice for this dumpster fire though. The vapid artificiality and preening self satisfaction of these two hollywood idiots was both awkward and amusing. At least its appropriately titled, Hollywood is the place where taste, class and artistic integrity go to die.

Straight garbage !! Saw it in the theatre first week it came out and then watched it again online a year or so later and my original review has not changed. Tarantino wanted to make some film that was a homage to a bygone era in Hollywood but he knew that would not sell so he included the Manson angle to suck people in. Didn't matter. The whole film was stupid and boring especially the middle hour. He disrespected a legend like Bruce Lee with a fictitious character and did his recent move which is to create some alternate history for an actual event. The Labiancas & Tate et al are still dead regardless of how talented  & clever the director thinks he is.

For example pretty much the entirety of Margot Robbies characters story has absolutely nothing to do with the main plot and only serves to add to the runtime, you could pretty much remove her from the movie and you'd have a faster and more focused story but that's not to say she's bad in the movie because she's actually fantastic, it's just a shame she's completely wasted here though. Overall it is an enjoyable movie that's definitely worth watching.

Just lost 3 hours of my life... what a complete, utter waste of time. How in the world this film is highly  regarded is a mystery, The  "acting" is good, the visuals are pretty, but there is zero plot, and not much interesting in terms of stand alone scenes except for a few minutes,

The chemistry between Pitt and DiCaprio is really nice, and Pitt's character is particularly compelling without necessarily being redeemable. The politics of the movie feel troubling ... particularly, advancing the narrative in which the Manson family stands in for hippiedom, and there is some kind of a culture war between hippies and, well, old-school Hollywood cowboy white guys who stand in for the norm. Having forgotten about the history, I found the class stuff at the end more remarkable than Tate. (Pitt goes to the hospital; DiCaprio goes to a party.) The movie gave me more I wanted to keep thinking about than I realized at the time.

Tarantino's inversion of the historical account offers a glimpse into the fairy tale universe where the "real" Hollywood tough guys get to make the leap into "new Hollywood". Sharon Tate's Kung fu is a sham but here in this dream world, the rough men intercept the psycho cultists and put the world right with nothing but a can of dog food and a flamethrower. A sweet dream of the spirit transformed from the "real" Hollywood circa 1969, described by Joan Didion in her famous book The White Album, a world of darkness, of bands "too cool" like the Doors, a world where no one was surprised when Manson crashed the party with his massacre, this world of "new Hollywood" gets a makeover. Manson is described as the flipside of charismatic cult leader, a loser who shows up at the Polanski residence looking for Terry Melcher (a fact according to at least one witness) but this is all you get from this cosmic nobody. This fairy tale rings true and I think it's Tarantino's best picture, better than Pulp Fiction by a mile, a love letter to a world that never was.
The movie has No story .Characters are introduced for no reason. what was the reason for having margot robbie or the hippie plot ?. The whole movie is dumb and pointless.

Once Upon A Time...In Hollywood - 9/10. It's definitely not for a film for everyone. The film takes its time in terms of moulding the story and tempo, but it delivers a cool nostalgic trip to the year 1969. Quentin Tarantino has crafted a film with much detail and superb performances! Leo and Brad deliver some solid and hilarious performances, with a shining Margot Robbie giving a subtle and bright performance as Sharon Tate. The rest of the ensemble cast deliver some great performances in their limited screen time, with Austin Butler and Margaret Qualley delivering standout performances within the ensemble cast. And, surprisingly, the film is probably his least violent film. I consider it as one of his best works, and definitely his most funniest film. A definite must watch!

A fantastic period piece from Tarantino.  Toned down shock and quirkiness making for a more enjoyable overall experience.  Memorable performances from Pacino and Pitt - probably my all-time favorite by Pitt.  Tarantino has found yet another film to blend the western theme with a contemporary subject.  And yes, Nazis get fragged in this film as well.

A Tarantino-esq. look at the Manson murder of Sharon Tate.  Also a look at the changing dynamic in entertainment and American culture from the traditional norms of the 50's-60's into the hippie era of the 70's.    There are a lot of layers here.  The dialogue is always crisp.   The acting is superb.    DiCaprio and Pitt are great in the dynamics of their relationships.   Margot Robbie is unappreciated in her mesmerizing performance as Sharon Tate.   The entire supporting case from Margaret Qualley, Bruce Dern, Al Pacino, and the rest are phenomenal.   Mike Moh is funny and exciting as "Bruce Lee".   Forget all the controversy from people that can accept an altered version of history that has Hitler burned alive but can't accept an over the top Bruce Lee- this was memorable.  The movie soundtrack is worth the whole thing even if you aren't a fan of the actual film.  You do not need to know the real version of events to watch this but you will smile if you do.

Once Upon Upon a Time In Hollywood – Even The Name is another ‘Borrowing' 
QT's latest indulgence is all about his one-way fixation with the ‘60s. At 160+ mins it's a long trudge but the script probably only had few pages if compared with other movies of this length, why?... So many scenes are made up of shots of bods getting into cars, then long internal shot from back seat (lifted from the far better  Gun Crazy' 50s) then bods get out of car, long shots of feet walking, more bods get into cars, more long internal driving shot, bods again get out of car, more feet walking. This format is repeated from beginning to end –pages of same--  The 60s heralded in a new low for movie making – features like; ‘Beach Blanket Bingo', ‘How to Stuff a Wild Bikini ', ‘Sergeant Deadhead' were playing as main features across the land, el-cheapo's had become the new norm. What would usually have been a ‘B' picture were now being sold as an ‘A'. Yes. it may have helped a jaded Hollywood at that time but what about other mainstream audiences?

So, what might have influenced TQs fixation with this downturn in the social morays of movies? Tarantino grew up in the swinging ‘60s/mod ‘70s working in a porn cinema (this perhaps explains his addiction to perversity) including a video store - while also watching the endless re-runs of TV shows, along with an overflowing barrage of low budget, Spaghetti westerns that had flooded the market - thank goodness some audiences grew up (well, some did) and demanded better.  These endless ‘homage's to days offering little more than cheap TV-style quickies -- now being released to the big screen --- with product that was generally catering for a guideless, acid tripping youth (such as the Manson crew, etc) wanting endless simple-minded partying. Hollywood producers loved it – now, for half the normal budgets, they were getting the same financial returns as quality features. 

QT has simply revived those days and a new ‘comic book hero' generation have picked it up. Only this time round, the budgets are BIGGER while the contents remain juvenile, if not ridiculous. Trouble is, too many of today's producers and art critics also grew up in this overly comfortable, ‘anything goes' era, so they wrap on about the glorious emptiness that's making them all rich. Some rave about the cinematography and design - with that much money being thrown about it's simple to ‘copy' the work of previous Masters. But, no matter how expensively dressed-up and stylishly packaged rubbish maybe, it's still rubbish (but, GOOD-LOOKING rubbish). Too much you might be saying? Take a look back, revisit many of those poorly scripted, badly acted, TV shows and movies of the 50s-60s – the ones Q.T. tends to dote over...you may be surprised how your memory may have failed you as just how poor most were.  

Once U.A.T.I.H. looks like several proposed projects that never got off the ground all edited into one, and doesn't do justice to any of them. One or two characters and situations looked as if they may have been leading to something but simply fizzled out. How long might it take before more look back and ask, how were we so fooled?  Or is it just that LESS has now become the new MORE?
So, if this is Q.Ts 9th may there be only one left to go. Please.

An amazing movie experience, specially because Tarantino takes his time. Although Margot screentime got all the attention, you have to highlight DeCaprio's performance, which is AMAZING. But Pitt is not far behind. Great, great movie.
It was the best film of 2019 by far!

I agree that the movie provides a raw truth about Hollywood and that there are some quite clever and funny moments. But I believe that there was no reason to take 3 hours from my time for this result.

what if you were my stunt double and we did everything together for 9 years and were slightly in love with each other all along and we're both boys...

anyway. i am delighted by and in love with this movie

As someone who has liked, disliked and loved some of Tarantino's previous work, and someone who's an avid consumer of quality cinema, I went in with some hype, some skepticism and mixed expectations. I had a slight idea what the movie was about, but I never bothered to dig deep into it before actually watching it. And since I believe I could've enjoyed it much more had I looked up the whole story prior, I highly recommend you do. It won't spoil the fun for you, it'll add up to it.

So I sat there, doing my best to just enjoy the movie instead of being too critical of it and looking too far into the scenes than I probably should, which certainly made for a better, more relaxed experience. The movie is long, and it being somewhat slow paced and patience demanding (which we're not always used to from Tarantino) could make it feel even longer, but if you're into that like I am, you know that's where the fun is at.

I smiled effortlessly at most of the scenes (because they were just THAT good) and even laughed with some of them, but one thing is sure, in classic Tarantino fashion, the writing and dialogue were absolutely ON POINT.

The casting could not have been better, each actor portrayed their character to mere perfection and they felt more like actual people than in any other movie I've seen.

Then comes the storyline, And I can't help but be a little biased here, seeing as my favorite movies are those that do nothing more than just tell you a story, the ones that make no effort to keep your attention. There's some events going on that you just have to follow, even if they feel like they're not leading to any peak or climax. This movie is a PRIME example of that. Perfect for people who like to get invested in a film rather than have it reward or gratify them.

And then it ended, leaving me, and everyone there I'm sure, STUNNED by what we had just seen, by how brilliant it all was and wishing we could watch the whole thing over again, there and then. It was a truly surreal experience.
It's nostalgic and the fights are composed very well. I heard about the California hippie culture back in the day but this movie gives the experience of how bad it was.

It doesn't work as breezy or mindless fun because of how bored I was, and it doesn't work as a compelling narrative or character study because it's clearly not trying to be. https://letterboxd.com/josephtomastik/film/once-upon-a-time-in-hollywood/

You don't hit "play" on a Tarantino picture with conventional expectations. I was perhaps surprised at how considered and thoughtful the script is, pacing slowly (but consistently) through a blend of real people and absolute fiction smoothly. It felt like it was building towards making a big point, but instead descends into hugely rewarding carnage - which isn't a criticism. In fact, the payoff for your patience and calmness is for jarringly brilliant (and potentially gratuitous) violence. If this is Quentin's last film, he's going out on a high.

Tarantino did a good bait-and-switch on me with this one, although the movie title should've tipped me off.

I watched this knowing next to nothing about it, and I know only the bare minimum about the real-world events, but when Sharon Tate and Polanski showed up, I felt pretty sure about the direction this was going (which is exactly what Tarantino wanted I guess).

When *that* night approached, with the the time-and-date overlays, I was convinced this was a story based on true events with a few fictional characters thrown in the mix. Needless to say, I was oh-so-wrong. After the slow and deliberate build-up, in the last chapter of the movie you get treated to a very abrupt and jarring transition into Tarantino territory. And then when the credits roll, the next surprise to me was that the movie almost has a feel-good happy end.

Performances are top-notch, and without knowing much about the setting, the meticulous attention to detail is obvious. I enjoyed this plunge into the late sixties immensely, and the cathartic burst of violence at the end was the cherry on top.

I'm a huge fan of Tarantino's, but this was a complete bore to me.  Indulgent and a love letter to himself and Hollywood.  Conciseness would've helped as the film was, in my opinion, about 45 minutes to an hour too lengthy.  

Also, there were a few scenes, particularly with the young actress Julia Butter's character, which were cringe worthy for their over sexualization.

Hard pass for me here.
its alright, give it a watch but don't expect it to be a mind blowingly good movie like some people say

The most mature and grounded film of Tarantino's incredible career. His supposedly penultimate film is also one of his best as a director. Outrageously funny and self-aware, he delivers everything you expect off him just differently. All the lead actors, Pitt in particular, nail their roles.

I don't really know where the movie wanted to go, there is lots of useless material in it, it isn't even exiting until the third act. A disappointment came from Tarantino. the fact that it was nominated for best original screenplay alongside the masterpiece Knives Out, is insulting. The movie is fine, nice camerawork, directing and acting, but it does not have a point to go.

Some characters fall flat and it can be a bit weakly paced at times, but as usual Tarantinoism- there is a very unconventionally told narrative filled with sick moments, beautifully shot scenes, immaculate screenplay and two outstanding performances from its two famed leads. It's also visually sharp and quite funny.

It is a super slow pace and boring movie. Leonardo DiCaprio's acting is fantastic, but unfortunately the worst Tarantino Movie so far. To be honest, the best part of the movie was the last 10 minutes of the climax.
A timeless, must see film.
One Upon a Time... In Hollywood is a funny and thrilling film, with a perfect ending, that exhales DiCaprio and Pitt's charisma - fitting all that's necessary to be a good Tarantino movie.
Great movie. Great actor. This movies transport you in Hollywood in that era with crazy story, plot, dialogue. Bravo

Ritorna la scrittura graffiante di Tarantino in un film molto più pacato del solito. Questa volta il regista manifesta il suo sconfinato talento in un contesto molto più descrittivo, nel quale prende il controllo di una ricostruzione storica maniacale e dettata da scenografie incredibili. Tarantino aveva già cambiato il corso della storia a suo piacimento, e questa volta lo rifà con un tocco molto più personale del solito, con una velata motivazione lasciata a piccole dosi in alcune scene specifiche lungo tutta la durata del film. Questo fa si che nel finale si sprigioni un delirio assoluto che va a completare con innovazione e sorpresa un quadro generale aperto fin dall'inizio dell'esperienza. Palese punto di forza del film è una totale sicurezza nell'approccio al film. Tarantino è totalmente a suo agio in un'opera che lo vede in pieno controllo del suo lavoro, a partire dall'immagine complessiva fino ad arrivare al minimo dettaglio. Non si può neanche dire che sia uno dei suoi film migliori, perché ormai ogni suo film è "uno dei suoi film migliori". Quello che è certo è che va a completare a pieni titoli una filmografia assolutamente leggendaria.
Sony Pictures, Columbia Pictures, and Quentin Tarantino's Once Upon a Time... In Hollywood is a very amazing film!!!
Great movie with the kind of ending you expect from Tarantino.

Only Tarantino could have made this good. Nothing really happens until the final half hour in a 160 minute picture, but do we care? This man could write the daily routine of an undertake and create a superb feature film. The dialogue is up there with some of the best that I have ever experienced. The visuals are amazing. It's clear that Tarantino put his all into this project, and it completely shows. Career-defining stuff from Pitt and DiCaprio, who sizzle together and excel apart. Robbie doesn't have much to do of interest in comparison and her moments in the spotlight are certainly a change of pace, but still emanate the same amount of fun. The rest of the cast also shines at so many various point that they escape description. The film would have been good with these baseline ingredients, but the ending is one of my favourites from any of Tarantino's. The glorious climax of brilliant humour and over-the-top violence will remain one of the greatest cinematic moments of the 21st century, and all of the film's self-indulgences pay off.
I have watched this movie over and over!!  One of my favorites! Everything about it is amazing.  If you are a true Tarantino fan then you will not be disappointed. See for yourself!

While not the most action-packed Tarantino film of his 9-film franchise so far and slow/boring in many parts, still of course awesome acting from Leonardo DiCaprio, Bruce Dern, and Brad Pitt. And to top it off narration from Kurt Russell of all people! Bruce Lee's portrayal was also sub-par at best.

My most eagerly anticipated movie of the year and I was a little disappointed with it. Not Tarantino's best but far from his worse either. The soundtrack wasn't as catchy overall (still had some gems but from top-to-bottom his soundtracks are usually top notch). Leo absolutely stole the show and continues to show why he's one of the finest actors working today. Brad did an excellent job complimenting him as well and their screen time together at times made the movie. Margot was a delicate flower throughout and was glad Tarantino humanized her. Unfortunately, due to the nature of her death she's viewed as a victim whereas this role gave her life. A very beautiful love letter by Quentin to the Hollywood of yesteryear. I'll check it out in theaters again!
Very well done.  Very entertaining.  Awesome storyline.

Only reason I give this a star is because the Bruce lee scene is hysterical.  The 
AST two minutes is alright but the rest of the movie is extremely boring and I mean almost unbearably boring.  Recommend either watching in a form you can fast forward or not watching.
this is the first Tarantino film I've ever seen so it's quite different. I still really like it with DiCaprio and Pitt giving extraordinary performances.

Wow!!! The first time I watched this film, I laughed all the way through. The dialogue is hilarious, the situations are hysterical. The great fantastic phenomenal movie starring Leonardo DiCaprio, Brad Pitt, and Margot Robbie. Sometimes you may feel that the movie is too long. But as you keep watching, the feeling of the movie is faster than you can imagine. Some scenes, I won't say which ones but they get brutal and kind like suspenseful and how the music sounds. Feel like you're in a horror movie which is weird but then you also feel like you're in a comedy then go to a drama. It's has everything feeling and has lots of fantastic scene. This movie has a ton of great actors that give a performance of a lifetime especially Brad Pitt. He's so enjoyable and also entertaining. In my opinion, he is better than Leonardo DiCaprio in this movie although Leo is in the movie more. But Brad Pitt's moments stand out more and more memorable. Margot Robbie to me felt like she having a role that is less attractive in the movie. I thought the movie would tie the three main characters together but they never did disappointing for me. (Spoiler alert!) The ending of the movie made me a little confused but Quentin Tarantino knows what he's doing and it's supposed to mean something so I'm intrigued. Overall, the movie is really good, it's fun, and there are a lot of feelings that make it perfect. This is definitely a great film and it is my second favorite Brad Pitt film of all time.
Nothing actually even happened in this movie. It's weird. And is Sharon Tate supposed to be pregnant here or what?
A story about an actor and his stunt-double that slowly unwinds into something much more sinister.

A relaxed Brad Pitt is akin to a cinematic massage. I liked Leo's scene with the child actor and Margot Robbie's scene in the theater. But overall, I felt quite bored with the two leads, whose time has passed both in their world and in mine. I just don't need stories about culturally expiring white men like this anymore, particularly when QT adds nothing new beyond his cinematic and physical fetishes (both also more fun in better movies).

Some great ideas and very good acting. The film is a bit chaotic while still being very entertaining. The nonlinear plot is not only a disadvantage. Perfectly enjoyable but not the best Tarantino has done. Some really good performances, 70s nostalgia, great music, pop culture references. All the usual refinements but something's missing. Nonetheless, I'd recommend it to any Tarantino fa s.
In love with this movie ! Brad Pit in his role actually perfect.

This movie is one of Quentin Tarantino's better works.  The fictionalized story of two Hollywood actors in the late 60's.  Great storytelling.  At no time was I  sure where the film was going.  Excellent camera work.  More importantly, Tarantino got the most out of his actors.  All performances were either good, very good, or excellent.  Leonardo DiCaprio made it into the 'excellent' category.  This movie may be worth watching twice.  It is nice to know Tarantino can still make a great movie, even though he is kind of an a**hole.

Tarantino, the Undisputed King of Happy Endings. I wondered where he'd go as he got older, this contains almost as much of his genius as the 1994 Magnum Opus.  Its not as good, but its just as warm. All the performances you'd expect aswell.  Lahvly.

Art imitating life or life imitating art is not an original idea, but it's one that is executed in a highly entertaining way in Once Upon a Time in Hollywood. The story loosely revolves  around the fictional lives of down and out actor Rick Dalton and his stuntman Cliff. Characters ride from one destination to the next in a sunny and vibrant 1960s wonderland accompanied by catchy songs and there are no clues as to what the audience can expect next story wise.  The fact that the movie doesn't try and bind the characters and narrative together allows it to blend fantasy and reality together in a highly organic way and the fluid transition between movie sets and real life locations and fictional movie scenes in a fictional movie are some of the obvious examples. The movie is funny and dramatic and wacky and touching and captivating and the take-away is that life is a story and we don't know what's around the corner and in those rare cases where we do get the satisfaction of knowing where a story is headed we're actually unlucky, because we'll never be surprised by it.
Nothing but the best from Tarantino in this mature apologist tribute to the Golden Age of Hollywood.

This was maybe the most boring movie I have ever seen. I don't care about the "bigger picture" and Sharon Tate, movie that long need something happening during it. There was nothing, and if there was something it was so irrelevant. You could probably watch last 10 minutes and miss nothing.
If some other guy had made this movie, everyone would be honest and say it is crap.

Once Upon A Time In Hollywood is a good movie from Quentin Tarantino. I love the acting from Leo and Brad, the alternative history storyline, the direction and production design. I do feel that the Bruce Lee segment was a bit tough to watch but hey it's Tarantino right. Overall, this movie really made my day into the 1960s.

QT is past his prime and his schtick is outdated and passe. This movie highlights this to a tee. Not only do we get drowned in his boyhood fetishes of bare footed, long legged young women/girls in jean shorts, but the explicit and implicit sexualisation of underage girls - and light weight racism cloaked in a "But That's How It Was In The 70s" disguise - wore me down. Is there still a palate for the ongoing portrayal of teenage girls as hot and horny bombshells seducing old crusty men? Is he trying to be edgy in this post-Weinstein era? Is he excusing pedophilia because "she came onto me"? Maybe. It's all bad taste, and not in a good way.

What I really liked about this movie is the entire middle of it. When its kind of rolling along at its own pace. In fact, these moments are so good that they warrant me to grant this picture a full five stars. Although there are what one might call flaws, taken altogether and tasted that away, the picture taste's like it was cooked by a master chef, no doubt about it. Movie people love the taste. They relish it. They relish this movie. 
The weakest link in this movie is without a doubt the entire Charlie Manson storyline. Not to mention the Bruce Lee arc which is also underdeveloped...unfortunately. The lack of development in some of these key areas feels like it was due to time constraints. But that is ironic because a picture like this one should not be constrained at all. That is indeed what we have come to expect from this genre. What genre you ask? The slice of life genre, I'd reply. Where setting takes top spot in terms of the overall story. Characters interact in interesting ways within the setting. And there really isn't much of a plot, certainly not like we would get from say a thriller or something. Not to mention there's not much special effects or action. In this movie the only action is from clips that are stitched in from movies that Rick Dalton starred in. Indeed, a movie like Inglorious Basterds seems like a giant successful production from the hollywood illustrated so finely in this movie. And that is the way that Tarantino does 'meta'. Back to the problematic Charlie Manson and his  cult of interesting hippie chicks and odd dog dudes. The movie ultimately ends with a climax that stems from this underdeveloped storyline- oddly missing the man himself, whose absence is not at all explained. Perhaps I might now wonder in Tarantino's what happens to Mr. Manson? But the audience probably wont wonder this because there is no hint, not even a subtle one, to wonder so. Indeed, what we come to realize is that there is a somewhat large bite size scene or two missing from this movie.

So, the first time I watched this film, I laughed all the way through.  The dialogue is hilarious, the situations are hysterical, and the big name actors are perfect in their portrayals.  The late 60's - early 70's is trademark Tarantino in any and every film he has ever done.  Exploitation-style Film & Television everywhere.   It's clear he is in love with both the Hollywood of his youth, and the last Hollywood of fantasy the USA ever knew.  By the 1980's, we were able to "peak behind the curtain", and all the mystique/PR/Bullshit was gone.

The second viewing, however, opened my eyes to enough nuance that I felt outright stupid in my initial reaction.  This film is an outright tragedy.  All the characters depicted are suffering and beyond salvation.  Everyone see DiCaprio at the end of his career.  Easy.  Everybody sees Pitt as tied to DiCaprio for whatever success he EVER had, include his present as a driver and "gopher".  What I missed the first time is Robbie's suffering; this woman goes to a movie theater ... staffed by people who do nothing except see movies ... and struggles to get their recognition.  Almost begs them to know who she is, naming film after film, role after role, and they never really know who she is.  Even though she is in the very film they are showing RIGHT NOW, they don't really know who she is.  When the booth girl ask for a photograph, she asks her to stand next to the poster so people will know who she is.

There is a massive subtext regarding the suffering and ultimate rejection by the vert people all of entertainment (Hollywood) are inextricably drawn toward; the fans.  On some level, the 21st century exploitation filmmaker of note created a fil.m that reveals how the real people the public claims to "love" are ultimately betrayed and abandoned by the very people they are trying to please, trying to gratify, trying so hard to win the acceptance and love of.  Us. The cussing-shooting-did-that-just-happen sensationalistic director actually gives an unflattering mirror reflection to the audience, exactly as Rick Dalton faces himself in his trailer, but there is no redemption for us.  Nothing like he finds by recommitting his-self to the role he has been cast in.

The central protagonist (Dalton) is cast in the role of the audience; An Evil Hamlet.
Most of the movie wastes time with them driving. Margot Robbie's character did not really play a big role or make an impact on the story. Overall, still a good movie, but did not need to be 3 hours.

One of the problems that great directors run into as they start to acquire fame is that they become so popular that everyone around them becomes a “yes man” and won’t refine the director’s vision, edit them, and restrain some of their obsessive tendencies. Once Upon a Time...in Hollywood is Quentin Tarantino unrestrained. There’s excess all over this thing, from the unnecessarily long run-time to the constant bare feet shoved in front of the screen. This doesn’t mean that he is so unhinged that the movie as a whole is a disaster. On the contrary, there are still some great elements in this film, despite its tendency to ramble on to a nearly exhausting degree. First and foremost, the acting is stellar. Brad Piitt is his usual charming self, and makes this stunt double into someone every guy would love to have as a friend. Leonardo DiCaprio is perfect as the actor struggling with the inevitable shift in his career from leading man/hero to supporting role/villain. As for how this movie handles the whole Manson family thing, I thought that was fine. It might have been more impactful to me if I was more knowledgeable about the history related to them, but I knew enough to appreciate this film and how it handled the historic tragedy. I genuinely loved the big climactic scene, and it’s not just because this was the most interesting part of the film (since something of note was happening.) It has this cathartic wish-fulfillment quality that you don’t see many other film-makers attempt. I only wish it felt more like the satisfying conclusion to a story, but there was so little structure to Once Upon a Time...in Hollywood. The entire thing felt like a series of small vignettes featuring a number of loosely-connected people, and then they all come together in the end for a big finish. It’s one of those movies where I simply felt like things were happening rather than a story was being told, which is a pet peeve of mine. Once Upon a Time...in Hollywood is definitely lower-tier Tarantino for me, even though it will be a favorite to others.
You can't go wrong with Tarantino... Always a Masterpiece... Love it.

The film assumes you know about Charles Manson and the Tate-LaBianca murders. If you don't have that knowledge, the film has zero tension and is merely yet another 'movie about making movies', a tiresome genre inflicted on us by Hollywood.

Absolutely loved it. Among its other charms, it is such a radical departure from most depictions of the late '60s. There was a seedy pathetic cloying grubby element to the hippies of the late 1960s, and this nailed it. And how "All-American" and square a lot of the United States was. People forget that, but it was not all day-glo peace and love in the '60s--by a long shot--and Once Upon a Time captures that diametric culture clash. All in all the film is quite absorbing. Fantastic acting. I'd gotten pretty tired of Tarantino in recent years but this was an inventive, well-made, smart, enjoyable film.

At almost 3 hours, this film is a slow burn, but with such an intimate and romantic portrayal of old Hollywood, you almost don't want it to end.  The leads each do what they do best; DiCaprio flawlessly portraying an aging star fraught with self-doubt, and Pitt defaulting to a gruff but vaguely wholesome stunt man.  With a mix of pure fiction and history, Tarantino builds tension by showing you the lives of the real life stars doomed to get caught up in Manson-family murders.  Sharon Tate is portrayed in uncanny fashion by Margot Robbie, whose talent and charm is ultimately under-utilized by Tarantino's script.  The film shows a commitment to long-winded and over-indulgent sequences that serve as love-letters to late 60s LA.  There are a few of these scenes that go bust, but most of them are fantastically entertaining.
Over rated and a bit simple. But Brad and Leo pull it off enough to enjoy the 9th film from Tarantino.

Once again Quentin Tarantino absorbs us into his visually stunning world where three hours pass in a flash and we barely notice the time has passed. Star power in spades isn't the only thing that lodges this entry of his into one of the greatest he has made. This stands easily next to Pulp Fiction and Reservoir Dogs. The attention to detail in the cars, marquees, locations, costumes, even props like beer cans and cigarettes is beyond impressive. The performances were stellar (Brad Pitt's Oscar was well deserved and I hope to see him and Leo work together again) and the story was engrossing. I loved his twist ending on one of Hollywood's most tragic and bloody stories. Even fictionalized, seeing Sharon Tate's killers meet a gruesome (and hilariously over-the-top) violent end was gratifying in ways cinema doesn't often deliver.

Once Upon A Time... In Hollywood is a "what if" historical fictional movie staring Brad a Pitt and Leonardo DiCaprio who are struggling actor and stuntman in 1960's Hollywood. At the beginning of the movie we learn Leo's neighbor is Roman Polanski and Sharon Tate played by Margot Robbie. The script takes us thru Leo's life and times on sets of cowboy movies with plenty of cameos such as Steve McQueen played by Damien Lewis and Bruce Lee played by Mike Moh. It was funny to see Brad kick Lee's ass which never happened; another what if event.  Al Pacino was Leo's agent who finds him roles in Italy where Leo gets married and has four movie roles all about westerns except for one bond-like flick.  Kurt Russell played an on-set supervisor and narrator of the fictional movie.  The latter half of the flick was more entertaining where the whole storyline could have been cut shorter and get to the point faster.   The true story of Manson family murder finds pregnant Sharon Tate hung by a rope along with three other individuals but in this what-if scene finds the Manson family entering Leo's house to find drugged up Brad to face the evil doings. Brad definitely deserved the Oscar win for Best Supporting Actor role.  Overall great direction, good script, great cinematography, and great actors but it was a bit confusing, it was good to watch once.

Where do I start,this movie a journey to the streets of L.A , a peek into the lives of a actor and his stuntman told in the most fascinating way in the time of Sharon Tate's murder time with a pinch of cool western clips.The great performances by Leo ( does this man ever gave a bad performance) and the ultimate cool Brad Pitt ( His best work to date) the innocent and brilliant Margot Robbie ( wish she had a bit more screen time ) and whole lot of unbelievable performances ( in particular by Al Pacino,Julia Butters,Timothy Olyphant,Margaret Qualley,Dakota Fanning and Bruce Dern).The writing by Tarantino is such a class even with almost 3 - hour runtime not a second is boring,you can't even change or alter one shot.The Cliff and Bruce scene,Rick's outburst and come back scene,the Spahn Ranch scene,Trudi's advise to Rick,Sharon watching her own movie,and of course the classic Tarantino climax and a lot more brilliant scenes.This movie is a bundle of joy with a lot of stand-out moments.The best work by Tarantino till date ( yes it is better than pulp fiction,at least for me).It's a MASTERPIECE.  96%

I have to say, I read many reviews and heard a lot of views regarding this film. It's not something I do very often because I choose to watch the film first and then see what others felt. But ‘Once Upon a Time in Hollywood' certainly divided opinion among critics and audiences alike, but for me I absolutely loved this film.

Essentially, there isn't much of a plot and I won't go into detail for anyone how hasn't seen it yet, but what I took away from this was that it seems to be Tarantino's film on the Film industry. To be more specific the ‘Golden Age' of Hollywood. That is what everyone has been saying and I couldn't agree more, because throughout the 2hrs 40 minutes of this, I wasn't bored at any point. Which many found themselves like when they watched it. The 3rd act possibly drags slightly but still enough to hold my attention. Brad Pitt and Leo DiCaprio's performances as stuntman Cliff Booth and Actor Rick Dalton received the acclaim they deserved, they were both phenomenal. Pitts supporting actor Oscar win was very much deserved in my opinion after seeing this. I can't really offer more than what people have already said. Margot Robbie's performance as Sharon Tate was acceptable, in a good way. I wouldn't say the inclusion of that character made the film what I thought it was, but it was a fine role that expanded the films narrative and it became relevant to the story. 

Finally, something that entertained me from start to finish and it has definitely become a positive through many of Tarantino's work is the soundtracks, and wow is this particular track a memorable one. Tracks such as ‘California Dreamin', ‘Hush' and ‘Brothers Love Traveling Salvation Show' were the ones that made fall in love with the film even more, and for me how good or bad the soundtrack compliments the film, ultimately can make or break how the film is received and this was a truly brilliant score.

So overall, I loved ‘Once Upon a Time in Hollywood' because it depicts the film industry in a fine era for cinema. And Tarantino shows just how much that era meant to him too. A very different Tarantino film, he shows his versatility here in abundance and for me, I would happily watch this over and over again.

Finally got to watch the latest Tarantino, ONCE UPON A TIME IN HOLLYWOOD, and I have to say that I was a bit unimpressed. While I can't deny the obvious love for film that Quentin has, and especially for that time period, which was a true shift in the industry from a more care-free style of film, to a grittier, angrier, more inventive approach brought upon by the disillusion associated with Vietnam, the hippie movement and the Manson murders. The film portrays that end of innocence pretty well by following a popular actor on the decline, Rick Dalton (played with full-blown anguish by Leonardo DiCaprio) and his long-time partner, friend and stuntman, Cliff Booth (performed with perfect tough guy cockiness by Bad Pitt), a friendship that reminds one of the rapport between Burt Reynolds and stuntman Hal Needham. Their paths crosses the grimy ones set by the Manson family and Sharon Tate.

Speaking of Tate, I can't say that I cared much for her portrayal by Margot Robbie. Through no fault of her own, but hindered by her role being badly scripted as a vacuous flower child. If the intent was to make her the symbol of the innocence that is in danger of being destroyed, it's a bit too much on the nose.

While there is the basis of a potentially fascinating story, Tarantino wallows in a bit too much of his self-indulgence, lingering too long o certain shots, and making sure he throws our way as many movie references as he can. Don't get me wrong; I'm a sucker for movies about movies, and I could have gone for more onset Hijinks by Booth and Dalton, especially the interlude in Italy hat could have been a movie by itself.

The Manson family moments could have brought a certain amount of tension to the film, but the whole flippancy expressed through every frame by Tarantino sabotages the stress we could have felt in those scenes.

He also goes back to his statement that a story beats History, and that the world is saved by art, by rewriting History like he did in INGLORIOUS BASTERDS and DJANGO UNCHAINED. While it was refreshing and unexpected in BASTERDS, it has lost a bit of its impact by now.

I know that I am going against the grain of many reviewers who are claiming it's a marvelous film, and I'll admit that I did fall in love with Brad Pitt's character enough that I would love to see other stories about him.

I feel this one wasn't the best one to tell.
