I'm really getting tired of the critics and fans giving movies high praise based solely on the director/writer.  Quentin Tarantino has been going downhill for the last several films and this was absolutely his worst.  This story dragged on, going nowhere.  Having to rely on narration to get the moviegoer to understand what is going on is not the type of movie he makes, but he couldn't get away from it.  In my opinion some of the best parts of his films are dialogs, intertwining story lines and bringing focus to the characters.  This film had none of that.  We are dragged through bits and pieces of forced character development, fragmented story lines, and a whole lot of going nowhere.  I'm sorry but if this film was made by an unknown filmmaker, I don't think anyone would be giving it good reviews (not even "OK" reviews).  Honestly this is like getting a really bad plate of food from a world famous chef, and reviewing that it was great based solely on the fact that it should have been great because of who made it.  Several of my top favorite films are Tarantino films, and I continue to watch them over and over again and introduce them to others for their enjoyment.  I cannot in good conscious do that with this film.  You can do so much better Quentin.  Please do better.

Visually, this is Quentin Tarantino at his most vibrant, most detailed, and his most stylish. The director does a brilliant job of recreating the 1960s pop culture iconography. His wide shots of busy main streets are visually stunning in the detail from billboards and movie posters, as vintage cars drive down the strip drenched in fluorescent neon lights against the dusk sky. Whereas vintage radio commercials for Heaven Sent perfume play in the background amongst the soundtrack ladled with supersonic sounds of the 60s. The director captures the period's sights and sounds so vividly, that the 60s Los Angeles backdrop feels incredibly lived in.

Leonardo DiCaprio (The Beach) delivers a fantastic performance as Rick Dalton, an insecure star who is on the decline. However, the feature belongs to Brad Pitt (12 Monkeys). As Cliff Booth, he's charming and incredibly fun to watch. Pitt brings a certain energy to each scene that keeps your eyes glued to the screen, waiting for his next move. Especially during the incredibly tense scene at Spahn Ranch. Margot Robbie (Harley Quinn: Birds Of Prey) is almost magical playing the actress Sharon Tate. Many critics bemoaned Robbie's dialogue-light portrayal of Tate. However, one could argue Once Upon A Time In Hollywood captures Tate's wholesomeness. Instead of being associated with death and macabre, Tate's life should be celebrated for the beautiful soul she was.

Upon release Once Upon A Time In Hollywood was billed as Tarantino's tale about the harrowing Manson-family murders. A home invasion nightmare that brought an end to the "Summer of Love" on August 9th 1969. Knowing this, there's a state of tension that lingers throughout. However, like Inglorious Basterds (2009), the historical record is used as a mere springboard for the directors fevered Imagineering. Tarantino takes the same route here inverting history, with Rick and Cliff turning the tables on the Manson family killers. The prolonged "What if?" violent finale is brutal and unapologetically satisfying. 

Overall, Once Upon A Time In Hollywood is a solid addition to Quentin Tarantino's filmography and serves as an ode to the golden age of Hollywood. The combination of fictional characters and real-life figures weave a revisionist tale around the event that arguably signalled the end of the "Summer of Love". It's more tender than the director's previous entry The Hateful Eight (2015), but still possesses most of the director's trademark shocking touches.

Another one of Tarantino's overhyped and alternative reality movies that really has little to say about today's times. In this film, Tarantino wraps himself in the allure of 1969 Los Angeles pretending that he has something to say about aging actors or random cult violence. But he really doesn't. If you break down the movie - the Tate story is only there to provide a 3rd act climax where villains that can be shot, mauled, bashed and burned alive. Otherwise, it really serves no purpose other than adding atmosphere and context to a somewhat drab main plot. The Rick Dalton main plot is just another rehash of stories we've seen before about a bad aging actor who's being pushed out of the business. Yeah it's Leo and Brad Pitt. So what? As Shania would say, "that don't impress me much."
As always, it's interesting to see how Tarantino breaks convention - like having a flashback inside a flashback - but if you're not a film nerd, this film may not be to your liking.  Overall, it's somewhat entertaining. But not the masterpiece that the lemming critics would have you believe. If you got nothing better to do for 3 hours, then go for it. But if you want and insightful look at the past and stardom, I highly recommend Almost Famous.

I want to enjoy movies and this one is extraordinary good.  It's a throwback to an era in history, even with all it's faults, there still remains an innocence in American culture that has long since past.  Thank you for still making movies for people who love them.

La cotidianeidad en 1969 de tres personajes:

- Rick Dalton (Leonardo di Caprio) otrora estrella de la TV y ahora reducido a papelitos de villano en series westerns y pensando si acepta filmar spaghetti westerns (que detesta) en Roma y ahogando sus penas en alcohol.

- Cliff Booth (Brad Pitt), su doble de cuerpo, devenido chofer, mandadero y amigo.

- Sharon Tate (Margot Robbie),  actriz y esposa entonces de Roman Polanski (a quien también se ve), vecina de Dalton y que pasea su belleza y melena rubia por media película y no mucho más.

Tarantino nos ofrece básicamente una comedia (sazonada con western y thriller entre otras cosas), una memorabilia plagada de referencias televisivas de los 50s y 60s (incluso recreando algunas de ellas) y de cameos de estrellas de entonces (y actuales): a veces parece que el film fuese sólo una excusa para todo ello.
También nos presenta sus típicos diálogos "que no conducen a ninguna parte" pero que incuban una amenaza de violencia, en un film larguísimo, con personajes unidimensionales (Tate es casi una rubia tonta) y totalmente episódico, falto de unidad y de crecimiento cercano a las 3 hs de duración.

SEMISPOILER: Puesto a elegir escenas rescatables, me quedo con el diálogo de Dalton con una niña actriz antes de una filmación (la increible Julia Butters: qué bien actúan lxs actorcitxs americanos), la visita de Booth al refugio de los hippies (siniestros) que invocan a un tal Charles y la secuencia final (totalmente injustificada argumentalmente) y que incluye una ucronía ampliamente espoileada que aquí no reveleré.

I've always been on the fence with Tarantino...they say genius and crazy is a fine line and I agree...where does this 1 sit...somewhere in the middle for me...The hollywood heavyweights of DiCaprio Pitt and Al Pacino carry the film for me...emphasis on Pitt...The story? This movie was far too long and boring. Many moments seem wildly unrealistic even by Quentin Tarantino standards. Another narcissistic Hollywood portraying Hollywood film that landed this movie a good score from the critics. Probably Tarantino’s worst film yet.
In his 9th film, Tarentino crafts some of his most likeable characters yet, and sets up possibly his best finale.

There are a lot of creative liberties, so don't look for historical accuracy –this film is above and beyond that. It is a nostalgic tribute to the Hollywood of old. The production design and cinematography are memorable, The camera follows all the action and accentuates every little detail of the characters and their emotions.

Quentin Tarantino likes happy endings. He likes them so much, in his imagination, he goes back in time and preemptively obliterates people responsible for history's nightmares, like the Holocaust, and the Manson Family murders which, for Quentin at least, did irreparable harm to the innocent chilled-out mood of Hollywood in 1969. 

In Tarantino's repaired world (called "Once Upon a Time in Hollywood") Clint Eastwood (or someone much like him) never became a bitter old curmudgeon arguing with a chair. Instead, he got cast in Roman Polanski movies mid-career and got to go to more parties and keep his chauffeur and personal stunt double. And the cool mood in Hollywood never got overrun by dirty hippies with no cars and their awful political correctness. 

Oh, people still get murdered in Quintin's world, but this time it's the right people: the political people, the radicals, the Nazis and people who will become Nazis, the people who will start killing if they haven't already. And this time the good guys win with every imaginable act of violence. The dirty hippies get mauled by dogs, smashed to a bloody pulp and charred by flames - just the sort of happy ending to make us all laugh and cheer. 

When I saw "Inglourious Basterds" I was struck by the irony of a scene within a scene: me sitting in a theater of people laughing at a revenge fantasy where Hitler is burned up with a bunch of Nazis as they sit in a theater laughing at a violent propaganda film about a German sniper endlessly shooting Allied soldiers from a clock tower until dead bodies are piled up. As flames envelope the screen I thought to myself "this is moral hell and Tarantino is holding up a mirror and showing his audience how they are like the Nazis delighting in righteous violence on the movie screen."

At the time I thought that this irony was intentional and Tarantino's "Basterds" movie was a clever morality play about the dangers of "preemptive war." I'm not so sure now. Perhaps Tarantino likes the idea of killing the bad people before they get a chance to kill us. And maybe he knows who should be allowed to pick the bad people: filmmakers (the old fashioned Hollywood kind), and actors who are childlike and innocent, and their no-foolishness stunt doubles who don't care about politics or activism. Or maybe the audience should decide what's fair in Movies and War. 

The only characters in "Once Upon a Time in Hollywood" (set in 1969) who say anything about the Vietnam War or inequality or politics are the criminally insane Charles Manson family members. Everybody else could care less about poverty or inequality - as they float in their pools and dance at the Playboy mansion - because they are the beautiful and harmless people who create the escapism of movies! Tarantino seems to be saying that Hollywood got ruined by politics and undue attention to the private lives of its creative flower children.

It's hard not to see "Once Upon a Time in Hollywood" as a subtle jab at the Me Too movement. Brad Pitt plays a likable guy who, it is said, "killed his wife and got away with it." But when an underage girl tries to seduce him he dutifully turns her down. Evidently Hollywood has a young girl problem. Roman Polanski is glamorized as the jet setting genius who made "Rosemary's Baby." Al Pacino plays a movie producer and kindly old-world father figure named Marvin Schwarzs (in contrast to Harvey Weinstein who produced most of Tarantino's movies). Sharon Tate, played by Margot Robbie, is the only sweet and likable woman in the movie. She's almost angelic. All the others are either nagging wives, Feminazis or underage jail-bate. The near exception is one 8 year old actress (she prefers to be called an "actor"). Yet even she takes issue when Leo Dicaprio's character calls her "pumpkin puss."

For all it's mystifying detail, "Once Upon a Time in Hollywood" is still a feast for the senses and a charming piece of nostalgia. Watching DiCaprio's insecure TV star character, Rick Dalton, melt down alone in his trailer after botching a scene is priceless. It may be Tarantino's most self-assured and well crafted movie to date. The violent finale plays like Three Stooges slapstick, and again, I found myself laughing at a woman getting her head smashed in, and another woman being burned up by a tool-shed flame thrower (left over from a previous movie). Remember, in the context of this movie, the Manson Family hasn't killed anyone, yet somehow Hollywood's grooviest times were rescued by the opportune violent killing of some hippies in place of Sharon Tate.

One has to wonder does Quentin Tarantino want us to reflect on these details or to just lighten up and laugh them off? I can't tell.

This review is really going to be very biased as the movies 🎥 of Quentin Tarantino is what got me into filmmaking. Pulp Fiction has been and always will be one of my favorite movies scenes I was way too young to see it. The stars ⭐️ Rick Dolten (Played by Leonardo DiCaprio) and his stunt double Cliff Booth (Played by Brad Pitt) with Sharon Tate (played by Margot Robbie) and their agent Marvin Schwarz (Played by Al Pacino) everyone does an amazing job in their respective roles ( especially Leo in his trailer which I bet Quentin told him I'm gonna leave the camera 📸 on for ten minutes here are some guidelines go nuts 🥜). Do I even need to explain why the cinematography was great it's Tarantino forte to shoot compelling dialogue scenes even if they're talking about something that doesn't relate to the overall plot? Speaking of which the writing ✍️ and directing is great 👍 but I will admit that some scenes do drag on a bit too long and the film really picks up in the end but that's just a nitpick. Real Rating: 77.5/100
Critics love Tarantino because he loves cinema and they can associate with that, and they get all of his references, which can be lost on your average viewer. It is the same reason movies set in LA often get a few noms or wins during Oscar season that many would call questionable. This is not to detract from Tarantino's talent. The man is a great writer, though as of late he has become a blowhard. Scripts are long and drawn out, and then they all crash into an ending that seems tacked on rather than built to which begs the question does he even know where he is going with his films anymore. It is not visionary, it is repetitive and showing very little sign of growth. He is a craftsman who carves an excellent movie each time, but they are more or less the same.

DE: Tarantino runs a decent ship, and Hollywood is no different. Everything seems to be on point. Every department is hitting its marks, and we are building a tale in his distinct (if that is the right word) style. In terms of editing, the loss of Sally Menke can be felt in every one of his films since she passed. She somehow was able to contain him and give a better structure. Though from seeing her works outside of the Tarantino verse, you can see he had an equal part in elevating her. Together they were able to take his longwinded approach and make it come off with a steady pace and allow decent investment from the audience, but now however that is slipping away at a fast pace with each subsequent film.

W: Tarantino is one of the great writers, he is not on Miyazaki's or Anderson's level, but he is undoubtedly on the same level as the Coen brothers or Bong Joon-ho. Which is not a level to sniff at, but the problem with Tarantino's writing is that he may have switched genres, but he has not adapted to it. More that he has made another Tarantino movie with a new shell on it. Which is great, but if I wanted to see the same thing as before I might as well watch the classics. It is sort of like a band doing a new tour 20 years later trying to flog the new stuff that sounds far too similar to the old stuff, and the fans would much rather prefer to hear the hits.

C: Have you seen a Tarantino, Scorsese or Oliver Stone movie? Then guess what you have seen Robert Richardson's work and along with it some iconic shots that have littered avatars and uni students bedrooms for decades. His outing this time is impressive, though it might not match a level that he created. That said the lens seems to tell more of a story here than Tarantino's writing, which tells you everything you need to know.

A: Acting is stereotypically cartoonish, but that has become a standard for Tarantino. Though Pitt's depiction of the more sane character throughout this 2D world of actors stands out. Sadly given the cast, we are working with, and the sheer level of talent coupled with the extent in which we examine these characters lives it feels underwhelming, and each one is more an allegory than a persona in their own right.

S: As strange as it seems the sound department is usually one of the reasons I watch a Tarantino film. Since Inglourious Basterds someone in the sound department is getting an Oscar nom, whether it is music, mixing or editing. Without fail Hollywood continues this trend. Just excellent.

PD: This film is not pretending to be the 1960s, it is the 1960s. I know you have seen many a period piece, and they all do a decent job, but it is the subtle nuances and the dirt that make the difference. This is not a glossy veneer trying to rewrite a section of history, this is just trying to capture an era for better or worse. This may be down to the fact that Tarantino is obsessed with the period and only a slight glance at his oeuvre would back this notion up.

BA: The costume design, while simple is also great, it catches the style of the era without feeling like it is overexaggerating the form or the zeitgeist of the time. The visual effects in the latter portion of the film while jarring are quite well done and stand out.

EVO: It is not one of Tarantino's "funner" films, which is odd given that it is a bright nostalgia backed film told from the perspective of mostly positive souls. If you are a Tarantino completest, you are going to want to see it, but for many, the question of why did I sit through that for 3 hours will ring true on the lips, and while the film is crafted brilliantly I cannot help but finding myself siding with them.

Tarantino has become iconic and actors salivate to play a role in his films, however he has not transcended beyond the guttural, gratuitous violence and shock factor that put him on the cinematic map. 'Once upon a time in hollywood' is a snooze fest wrapped as a love story to glory days. The payoff in the last 20 mins was anti-climatic. None of the characters were memorable, rather washouts and full of self doubt. The biggest proof that this was a weak installment is the fact that not a single meme has entered popular culture from this film, unlike Tarantino's other works. Similar to 'The Last Jedi', the critics are falling over themselves to praise his snooze fest, out of FOMO than anything else. If Tarantino intends to end at film 10, he better knock it out of the park, otherwise unlike Michael Jordan, he will leave too late.

If you enjoy the subtle humor and slow burn story telling of filmmakers like the Coen Brothers and (of course) Quentin Tarantino, you might just love Once Upon a Time in Hollywood. The performances, especially from Pitt and DiCaprio are superb, the cinematography is basically flawless. Every shot could be a still picture with perfect composition. Every scene is basically a vignette short story that could stand on its own, and if there is any flaw in the movie, that's probably it. It's less about plot, and more about interesting and likable characters put in situations that range from mundane to utterly ridiculous. It's possible that the average movie goer will overlook  some of the little bits of ubiquitous humor and nostalgia, and if so, the movie could feel slow, and perhaps even boring. But if you enjoy all the little things that make a Tarantino film a Tarantino film, this is for me, his most lighthearted (with the exception of a couple scenes) and his most "watchable" movie to date. I will be re-watching this in the same way I have re-watched movies like Fight Club, or the Big Lebowski. The characters are magnetic and there are lots of little things to notice and enjoy if you're looking for them.

It was so worth it, and it was like a good read. You put it on the shelf and pull it out when you really need it. Also, okay, never mind, nobody spoiled this one for me, no one gave me a clue, so I'm not going to do it to you by explaining what, exactly, it has in common with "Inglorious Basterds," and don't mean Brad Pitt doing the drawl which reminds me of my Missouri relations. How can I say it and keep from ruining the story for those that haven't read it yet?  Look. Mr. Tarantino will occasionally present a revisionistic take on a historical subject that gives those who suffered vicariously, a relief valve that I, for one, never knew I needed until I got it.

I believe they captured the time period in amazing fashion and detail, even down to a soundtrack which doesn't include the stereotypical songs. For these reasons, you can get to 2 stars, but as a movie, it was terrible except for the last 10 minutes and a few scenes here or there. If you have to go outside the movie to get the plot, then you have failed as a storyteller, and assuming that the entire viewing audience is intimately familiar with the happenings of the Manson Murders is a glaring mistake from the get go.

La novena película de Quentin Tarantino y tal vez la más Tarantino que ha hecho. Su filmografía siempre se ha basado en homenajes a clásicos del cine y de esto se trata esta película de: cine. Basada en el fatal asesinato hecho por la familia Manson a la esposa del director Román Polansky, Sharon Tate (interpretada por Margot Robbie). Es increíble como Tarantino aún escribe guiones tan interesantes y divertidos, realmente es satisfactorio ver está película, es súper graciosa y llena de momentos de tensión como solo Tarantino lo puede hacer. Para mí es algo más simple de lo que suele hacer, pero es tan entretenida que el tiempo se va volando y es divertido ver los guiños a Hollywood y el final es simplemente Tarantinesco (Estoy seguro que no existe esa palabra pero solo así lo puedo describir). Y claro no olvidar la fotografía hermosa y las actuaciones de nivel que Brad Pitt y Leonardo DiCaprio nos tienen acostumbrados.

Se amolda junto a las demás películas de Tarantino en cuanto a grandes diálogos, escenas y organización del guión; pero carece de fuerza para mantener el relato hasta el final debido a su extensa duración. Tiene grandes personajes muy bien interpretados, pero que no se sienten tan relevantes en la historia. Al final de cuentas, es una de Quentin, rara y alocada, y bien llevada a la pantalla grande.

Wish Fulfilment

Tarantino's scrupulously reconstructs 1969 Hollywood to create an alternative end to the 1960's, but to what end? Once again, he has made an enjoyable, overlong and seemingly pointless re-imagining (think Inglorious Bastards, Hateful 8, etc) that pervades his private fantasies, instead of an original narrative.

Of course, 1969 featured Woodstock and Altamont, but the Manson killings was the quintessential, bleak end of that exciting decade. And here, Tarantino imagines a clear clash between early 1960's macho culture confronting a debased late 1960's hippie disaster, with the macho culture coming out on top. With both Pitt and DiCaprio on top form as a tough stunt man (think Clint Eastwood) and fading, insecure Western star (no obvious parallel I know of), most of the film seems to be wallowing in their relationship. But the real story is the scheduled murder of next store neighbour Sharon Tate by the Manson crazies in August. We are waiting for it - how will Tarantino deal with it? It will be gruesome that's for sure. But what do these macho neighbours have to do with it?

Well, that's the real tale. What if the Manson family made a slightly different turn and missed Terry Melcher's old house and invaded Leo and Brad's pad? Quite a different outcome from the real story. The blood bath was on the other foot, with the macho boys dispensing ruthless frontier justice on the home invaders.

Despite the length, I found it captivating, weird, beautiful and disgusting all at the same time. The message was clear - if drug crazed hippies are out to kill you, a couple of tough guys with a pit bull and a flame thrower will save you from a fate worse than Covid-19.

Not a perfect film, but a wildly enjoyable romp.

My Netflix review, repurposed: I like Tarantino. I like this film. It's not boring or over long as some reviewers think. It's not inaccessible to people who didn't live through the '60's as written in some media reviews, because if that were true, all of the films I've watched & enjoyed that were set in the Stone Age (Quest For Fire), the Roman Empire (I Claudius), the Middle Ages (Marketa Lazarova) the 16th, 17th, 18th (Jane Austin's "Emma" or "Pride and Prejudice") 19th ("Wuthering Heights") centuries & the complete 20th century (everything), wouldn't have been relatable to or understood by me. I wasn't bored by THOSE films because I'm a reader. I had a good public education. I strived for the best grades I could get in K through 12, I didn't drop out or ignore my teachers during class and I did my homework. I went to college by working from age 14, saved every penny, got huge loans that took me 30 years to pay off, & I received a good education that required me to read, read, read, & learn from my instructors & professors how to interpret those books, whether text books or novels or non-fiction writings. It expanded my brain so that I am able to do the same thing with movies, so I'm not bored by them. I can enjoy movies that are really well crafted like this one. This film is the work of an evolving director, who didn't "make up a stupid boring long thing with too much talking about something that didn't even happen that way" (I'm not quoting anyone. I'm combining all of the negatives I've read/heard everywhere into one paraphrase). He gave us a "what if", & nice "if only". It's not boring. Tons of funny things happen in short bursts throughout the film & are cleverly brought back together in that final blast that is the ultimate Tarantinoed "what if" that pays homage to Sharon Tate & the others who were tortured & killed by the Manson Family. It might disappoint a Tarantino fan who has not yet matured at the same rate. It might be better later, with more accrued observation/thinking skills.

I tried watching this film five times and always turned it off. I finally got through it, even fast forwarding thru sections of the film, to finally finish it was pretty unbearable. Tarantino's worst film to date! My first thoughts after finishing the film were ''what a piece of shit''. I habe never said this about any of his films and it is a shame. This unimaginative version of real life events skewed to Tarantino's will, was boring, overly long (by about an hour) and just muddled story of a falling Hollywood star and his decent from stardom leave much to be desired. This may have been a decent film on it's own prwemise but the added mix of the Tate/Manson murders just doesn't work. Expected better from a giant. The only decent parts of the movie are Brad Pitt and sadly, the best part of the film was the dog.

I agree it's meandering and underwhelming. But it is a coolly acted, beautifully produced movie which reminds us of a shift in Hollywood in the 70s and how it mirrors Hollywood today, which is changing ever more rapidly. If Tarantino had utilized the premise's potential more, it would make a strong contender.

In the late 60s, the actor Rick Dalton tries to adapt to the new times. His double and best friend, Cliff Booth, has problems to find a job because people think he killed his wife. Also, Cliff has to move Rick around by car because Dalton's driver's license has been suspended due to drive drunk. At the same time, a relationship is born between Rick and actress Sharon Tate, who was a victim of the Manson family in the 1969 massacre.

From writer/director Quentin Tarantino comes the period drama Once Upon a Time…in Hollywood.  A "what if" historical fiction like Inglourious Basterds, the film looks at the 1969 Manson Family Murders  supposing that an aging action star and his stuntman had been living next door to Roman Polanski and Sharon Tate.  Featuring Leonardo DiCaprio, Brad Pitt, Margot Robbie, Kurt Russell, and Dakota Fanning, the film has an impressive cast; though most of the roles (apart from DiCaprio and Pitt) are little more than extended cameos.  And the pacing is incredible slow, fetishizing old Hollywood as Tarantino is want to do.  Still, his penchant for witty, engaging dialog is in full effect.  While it meanders about too long and its blurring of fantasy and reality feels like a cheat, Once Upon a Time…in Hollywood is entertaining and fun (to a point).
Interesting, but a little bit tedious.

"What if Charlie Manson's cult attack on swanky entertainment persons of L.A. were made instead against, umm, more of a down home type guy?" seems to be the essential question of this look at California culture in the late 60's, inundated as it was with incessant media aimed at pleasure and mayhem. In the meantime we lackadaisically are lead to follow a faded actor's attempt to resuscitate his career while in that environment, as well as that of his stuntman best friend. This adventure is interesting while not essential to the story, which nonetheless is (ala typical Tarantino) topped with a violent climax. Worth watching again? You bet. Great realisation? Incredible.

I now have watched Once Upon A Time in Hollywood...It's a lonnng film... watched at 2 sittings.. but Mark Lindsay had raved on about it... due to fact there's lots of Raiders music used... lol... AND it was the film for which Brad Pitt was award the Oscar for best supporting actor... ohhh... I just looked this up.. Leo D was up for best actor for the film but Joaquin Phoenix beat him out...hmmm... I thought Leo and Brad were both up for best actor for the film... whyyyy... lol.. I sat watching thinking... through the film.. that Leo should have received the award (thinking he was up against Brad) because he ... imo... out acted Brad... I thought Leo was really really good in the film.. and then... came.. CRIM... the last 10 minutes or so of the film and I thought Brad deserved the Oscar... remember... against Leo... I didn't know how any one could choose... I loved the acting of both... I couldn't understand ... really... the ... relationship between the characters... or could... or not... lol... it was weird... or not... BUT... the side story... maybe the main ? was the story of the Manson family ... Charles Manson... The last 10 minutes or so... had me laughing out loud... but... many probably wouldn't... You'd laugh if you like the over the top violence.. in... OH WAIT... lol... I get it now... Once Upon A Time In Mexico... lol...or not... and then the final scenes... I sat in creepified awe thinking... "I see what you did there, Quentin Tarantino" ... Maybe this is a film for those who lived during that period of time... whose psyche was affected by the crimes of Manson ... At any rate... I really liked it ... I remember going to the film rental store as a kid once every month, and by that time it was very odd for a kid my age to rent movies such as ‘Taxi Driver' ‘Psycho' etc. instead of early 2000s kids movies. And I remember that time when my mother bought me a 35mm film print for ‘Pulp Fiction' because we had a 35mm projector that we never used. I started watching ‘Pulp Fiction' once every week, and that's how I knew about the legendary director Quentin Tarantino. In 2019, Columbia Pictures released Once Upon a Time in Hollywood, written and directed by Quentin Tarantino.

  Tarantino's 9th film is perhaps the most -Tarantino-esque- of all his movies to date, it's a love letter to Hollywood and cinema. The film is packed with great characters, memorable locations of 1960's LA, spectacular writing, perfect production design, amazing cinematography and Tarantino's unorthodox great directing techniques. The film consists of something from every Tarantino film starting from long car rides, (spaghetti) westerns, WW2 adventures, martial arts to Tarantino's grindhouse style.

In terms of story, actor Rick Dalton (Leonardo Di Caprio) a serious drinker, who once were a successful star for a very successful TV show called ‘Bounty Law' is watching his film career diminishing and he's starting to play the bad guy (supporting roles) against new coming talents, while having breakdowns on set. It's also about his stunt double and best friend Cliff Booth (Brad Pitt) who were described as "A buddy who's more than a brother and a little less than a wife", Cliff is a formal green beret in WW2, whose Hollywood's career diminishing as well since Dalton is not getting any roles, so he's just Dalton's drinking partner and he drives him around since Dalton driving's license was taken away for too many drunk driving tickets. It's about the beautiful Sharon Tate (Margot Robbie) a rising Hollywood star who lives with her husband Roman Polanski (Hollywood's best director by that time) next door to Dalton on Cielo Drive, which makes Dalton questions himself if he might be one pool party away to star in the next Polanski film to revive his acting career. The story leads to the miserable night of 8 August, 1969 when the violence of the Manson Family happens (The day the Manson Family kill Sharon Tate in real life).


The first act starts when Rick and Cliff went to Musso & Frank Grill to meet Dalton's agent Marvin Shwarz (Al Pacino) where Shwarz tells Dalton the ugly truth, that he has to go to Italy and starts starring in Spaghetti Westerns instead of playing the bad guy in Hollywood because that'd bring down his career even more. When Rick and Cliff left the restaurant, Rick kept on crying and cussing because his agent told him that he must go to Italy, Cliff then takes Rick home to study his lines from a show that he'll be acting in the next day while drinking margaritas in his pool. After Cliff drops off Dalton at his fancy house in Cielo drive, he parks Dalton's 1966 Cadillac Coupe de Ville and takes his 1964 Volkswagen Karmann Ghia and goes home, when Booth arrives home aka a dirty trailer next to Van Nuys Drive-In Brandy his dog was waiting impatiently for Cliff to come back home so he can feed her from the Rat flavored canned food while making mac n' cheese for himself. At the same, the rising star Sharon Tate goes to a party at the Playboy Mansion with her husband Roman Polanski who were with their friends including actor Steve McQueen.

Act two starts when Cliff picks up Rick in the morning to take him to his film set, where Dalton was absolutely hungover. When they arrive on set, Cliff asks Rick if he can be his stunt double on this show but Rick told him that the stunt coordinator is friends with someone named Randy who once had a problem with Cliff, and then he told Booth to go back and fix his roof antenna. While fixing Rick's roof antenna, Cliff remembers this and a flashback begins, the flashback starts when Rick was filming an episode of ‘The Green Hornet' and Randy (Kurt Russel) is in charge of stunts, the scene starts inside Rick's trailer on set where he asks Randy to hire Cliff because he likes working with him. Randy explains that he doesn't like Cliff because he killed his wife; at this point, another flashback starts where we see Cliff, drunk on a shaky boat with his nagging wife Billie (Rebecca Gayheart) as she fights him, Tarantino frames the scene where we only see Cliff holding a fishing harpoon angled align with Billie, so I guess we could imagine what happens next. Randy then decides to hire Cliff but he told him not to get near to his wife Janet (Zoe Bell) because she hates him. Cliff then goes on set where Bruce Lee (Mike Moh) giving a speech about martial arts saying that he'd beat Muhammad Ali, Cliff laughs and grabs Lee's attention and got him furious which made Bruce ask Cliff for a friendly martial arts contest to see who's going to win, Cliff ends up throwing Bruce on a car on set that led to smashing it, the car happened to be Janet's which got her very angry so she kicked Cliff off set. Then we go back to Cliff on Rick's roof approving to why he didn't get the job. Meanwhile, Cliff was suspecting someone who just entered Cielo Drive, which happened to be Charles Manson (Damon Herriman).

In the same time, Rick was in the makeup trailer where he met the show's director Sam Wanamaker (Nicholas Hammond) who wanted him to look as a hippie because that's how successful actors looked like by that time. Rick then goes to the Bad Guy's salon where the scene takes place, Rick then meets a kid on set Trudi Fraser (Julia Butters), who was even more charismatic than rick was. Rick starts telling her about the book that he has been reading and starts crying because it has the same story as his acting career. The other scene takes us to Rick acting on the show where he keeps forgetting his lines and embarrassing himself even more, after that Rick went to his trailer for a memorable jump cut scene where he kept shouting and breaking the glass, then he made a promise to himself that he'll go back and get the job done. After some phenomenal acting from Rick, Trudi went to him and told him that this was the best acting she ever saw in her whole life, Rick then started crying because he was so happy.

In the same time, Sharon went to Hollywood Boulevard to buy a gift for her husband, until she saw her film's poster ‘The Wrecking Crew' in one of the theaters, so she decided to go in and watch the film. Meanwhile, Cliff was driving around when he saw Pussycat (Margaret Qualley) a hippie girl that Cliff has been seeing for two days, she asked him to take her where she lives at the Spahn Ranch (which was a movie ranch in late 1940s to early 1960s, that is now a place for the hippies aka the Manson Family). When Cliff arrives at Spahn Ranch with Pussycat he started noticing some changes, and then he asked everyone if George Spahn (Bruce Dern) still lives here until he forcefully enters his house where he had a sharp conversation with Squeaky (Dakota Fanning) who was the responsible for the place after Charles Manson. After she made him enter the house, she tells him that George is now blind so he must tell him who he is; this scene was the most suspenseful scene in the whole film, which ended with a funny conversation between Cliff and George. Cliff then beats one of the hippies for cutting Rick's tire and made him fix it. At the end of the day, Cliff picks up Rick from set and takes him home, the two of them decide to have a movie night to watch an episode that Rick acted in; in the same time, Marvin Shwarz was watching the episode while calling an Italian director to tell him to open TV and watch Rick's part.

Act three starts 6 months later when Rick and his new Italian wife Francesca Capucci (Lorenzo Izzo) are on an airplane going back to LA alongside with his partner Cliff Booth, after having a successful acting career in Italy. Meanwhile, Sharon Tate is now very pregnant spending her day with three of her houseguests – Voytek Frykowski (Costa Ronin), Abigail Folger (Samantha Robinson) and her best friend Jay Sebring (Emile Hirsch) while her husband Roman Polanski was out of town. At night Sharon and her friends go out for dinner at the Mexican restaurant El Coyote. Meanwhile, after getting back to the house from the airport, Cliff picks up his dog Brandy, Rick putting jetlagged Francesca to bed; Rick and Cliff also head out to a Mexican Restaurant Casa Vega. Around 10pm Sharon and her friends went back to her house in Cielo Drive, while Rick and Cliff decided to go back home to continue their night.

Meanwhile, three of the Mansion family were in Cielo Drive getting ready to murder Sharon Tate (that's what happened in real life) but this time, Rick confronts them about disturbing the neighborhood with their busted muffled car. After that, the followers of the Mansion Family decides break into Dalton's house instead, but they were surprised to find Cliff, who's gotten high off an acid-dipped cigarette, but somehow he remembered them from the day he went to Spahn Ranch; this is where the TARANTINO-ESQUE VIOLENCE ending occurs, with the help of Cliff's Pitbull, Cliff fights them off, eventually killing Tex Watson (Austin Butler) and Patricia Krenwinkel (Madisen Beaty) (Long story) in a party of violence that recalls the blood soaked ending of ‘Django Unchained' and ‘Inglourious Basterds'. On the other hand, Dalton burns Atkins in the pool with her flamethrower (the one he used in his film ‘The 14 Fists of McCluskey'). The cops were called to pick up the dead bodies, and then Rick receives what he's been wishing for the entire film, an invitation to have a drink with Sharon Tate. Could this be the pool party Rick has been wishing for so he could rise again?

Who else other than Tarantino would change history and give Sharon Tate another summer to live? Who else other than Tarantino would include a total of 5 minutes of car rides where Cliff drives around Hollywood Boulevard, flawless music when he played ‘Mrs. Robinson' when Cliff first met Pussycat (Margaret Qualley), Barbara Ling's perfect production design who won an Oscar for that film and Robert Richardson's flexible camerawork and his nostalgic warmth cinematography.

In February 1969, veteran Hollywood actor Rick Dalton (Leonardo DiCaprio), star of 1950s Western television series Bounty Law, fears his career is waning. Casting agent Marvin Schwarz (Al Pacino) recommends he make Spaghetti Westerns in Italy, which Dalton feels are beneath him. Dalton's best friend and stunt double, Cliff Booth (Brad Pitt) — a war veteran skilled in hand-to-hand combat who lives in a tiny trailer with his pit bull, Brandy — drives Dalton around Los Angeles because Dalton's driver's license has been suspended due to DUI. Booth struggles to find stunt work in Hollywood because of rumors he murdered his wife. Actress Sharon Tate (Margot Robbie) and her husband, director Roman Polanski, have moved next door to Dalton. He dreams of befriending them to revive his declining acting career. That night, Tate and Polanski attend a celebrity-filled party at the Playboy Mansion. The next day, while repairing Dalton's TV antenna, Booth reminisces about a sparring contest he had with Bruce Lee on the set of The Green Hornet which resulted in Booth being fired. Meanwhile, Charles Manson stops by the Polanski residence looking for music producer Terry Melcher, who used to live there, but is turned away by Jay Sebring (Emile Hirsch)...

Rotten Tomatoes critical consensus reads, "Thrillingly unrestrained yet solidly crafted, Once Upon a Time in Hollywood tempers Tarantino's provocative impulses with the clarity of a mature filmmaker's vision." The Hollywood Reporter said critics had "an overall positive view," with some calling it "Tarantino's love letter to '60s L.A.," praising its cast and setting, while others were "divided on its ending." ReelViews' James Berardinelli awarded the film 3.5 stars out of 4, saying it was "made by a movie-lover for movie-lovers. And even those who don't qualify may still enjoy the hell out of it." RogerEbert.com's Brian Tallerico gave it four out of four stars, calling it "layered and ambitious, the product of a confident filmmaker working with collaborators completely in tune with his vision". The Chicago Sun-Times, Richard Roeper described it as "a brilliant and sometimes outrageously fantastic mash-up of real-life events and characters with pure fiction," giving it full marks. Writing for Variety, Owen Gleiberman called it a "heady engrossing collage of a film—but not, in the end, a masterpiece." Peter Bradshaw of The Guardian gave it five out of five stars, praising Pitt and DiCaprio's performances and calling it "Tarantino's dazzling LA redemption song." Steve Pond of TheWrap said: "Big, brash, ridiculous, too long, and in the end invigorating, the film is a grand playground for its director to fetishize old pop culture and bring his gleeful perversity to the craft of moviemaking." Peter Travers of Rolling Stone awarded the film 4.5 out of 5 stars, remarking that "All the actors, in roles large and small, bring their A games to the film. Two hours and 40 minutes can feel long for some. I wouldn't change a frame." The film also garnered moral and theological praise. The Los Angeles Catholic Bishop Robert Barron praised the character of Cliff Booth as embodying the four cardinal virtues, while the theologian David Bentley Hart wrote that the film "exhibit[s] a genuine ethical pathos, one that actually brought tears to my eyes" for its portrayal of "cosmic justice." Specifically, Hart praised the revisionism when "Tarantino's version of the story unexpectedly veered away into some other, dreamlike, better world, where the monsters inadvertently passed through the wrong door and met the end they deserved" that "gave glorious expression to a perfectly righteous rage" in "some other order of reality, if only an imaginary one, where ethereal sweetness had survived and horror had perished."

I think he is running on empty at this point in his career. There´s not gas left. 

Trivia: The movie can be seen as revisionist fiction, with several made-up characters interacting with existing ones, thereby changing the course of real-life history. In this case, the infamous Sharon Tate murders by members of Charles Manson's 'Family' are disrupted by the presence of Rick Dalton (Leonardo DiCaprio) and Cliff Booth (Brad Pitt). The film accurately shows Charles Manson (Damon Herriman) visiting Tate's house early in the film, looking for music producer Terry Melcher (the previous renter) because he felt that Melcher owed him the record deal that he was once promised. Frustrated that Melcher no longer lived there, Manson instructed four of his followers to go to the house six months later, to incite a slaughter. The four indeed drove over there, briefly parked on the driveway to cut the phonelines to Tate's house, then proceeded to park the car at the bottom of the hill, went back to the house on foot and killed five people (Tate, three of her friends who happened to be at the house, and one friend who just came visiting). Probably the first significant point of divergence between the real and fictional account is the fact that Dalton notices the four as they are parked on the driveway. He gets out, verbally abuses them and sends them away. This angers Tex (Austin Butler) and the three women to the point where they decide to come back and invade Dalton's house instead. This incident also causes the woman called Flowerchild (Maya Hawke) to get cold feet, and leave with the car (in real life, this was Linda Kasabian, who accompanied the others all the way but did not participate in the killings). In the end, the fatal mistake on the part of the killers is invading Dalton's house, not counting on the resistance of Booth and his dog, and Dalton himself.

Wow!  I wasn't sure what to expect from this movie, and I found it quite astonishing.  In one way it's a simple movie, and yet there were so many layers I imagine writer/director Quentin Tarantino likely intended.  For instance: maintaining a reverence for pop culture while scrutinizing reality vs "Hollywood"; a pure examination of actors jobs vs the people in the job; the power of art; the way the music was used; the beauty in the cinematography of the settings.  And Quentin Tarantino's cleansing vision of the fate of Nazis and Manson family members was very satisfying, similar to the bloodbath scene in Django Unchained.  I enjoyed all the actors in their roles; Leonardo DiCaprio's acting in particular was memorable.  Thanks for this!

Can Tarantino make a film without shamelessly calling attention to himself via signature illogical quirk indulgences? One which comes to mind is the ridiculous scene at the Manson dwelling ranch where Brad Pitt forgets he habitually merely plays, however effectively, at superheroic achievement against incredible odds. 

On a larger scale, where history is not merely bent a bit, but completely upended at the culminating point in the storyline, we have to ask ourselves to what artistic end? If our aim is to be entertained as in yet again further "refreshed", some will find such an indulgence reasonable. It just seems to me, there was much well done in a film ultimately smothered by boundless ego.

I would strongly suggest that you familiarize yourself with the Charles Manson cult and the Sharon Tate murder BEFORE you watch the film--That will no doubt enhance your overall enjoyment level.  Perhaps if I had been more familiar with the real life people the characters are based on, I would have liked the movie more. I'd say that speaks volumes to the talent of Mr. Tarantino, wouldn't you?

Revolving around and driven entirely by its characters, ‘Once Upon a Time in Hollywood' has no discernible narrative to follow and certainly breaks the mould. It's exactly those qualities that will put some off, especially those expecting something more familiar and less tame.  

That being said, I personally think Tarantino has, once again, delivered a gem of a film with masterful writing and directing (the characters, the production design, the visuals, the soundtrack – I love it all), as well as magnetic work from an insanely talented cast who fill the screen with charisma.

What it really is, is a look at a particular time in Hollywood history as seen through the iconic director's eyes – a strange and unusual love letter to it, so to say – and that won't be for everyone. For me, it was captivating from its beginning to its very Tarantino-esque ending that was the icing on the cake.
Tarantino can create nostalgia for a time you didn't even live in.

An increasingly irrelevant television actor, Rick Dalton (DiCaprio) and his out of work stunt double, Cliff Booth (Pitt) strive to achieve fame and success in the film industry as Hollywood's Golden Age comes to an end. Tarantino crafts yet another masterclass in classic film making technique and ever engaging dialogue in this stylish revisionist history of 1960s L.A. 

Tarantino is without a doubt one of the most skilful directors working today and he surrounds himself with a very talented cast and crew who are all working brilliantly in this his ninth film. The cinematography by Robert Richardson strikes a clever balance between modern camera movement and a more classical filmmaking style paying homage to films from the 50s and 60s with plenty of long wide takes showing off the wonderful work from production designer Barbara Ling and costume designer Arianne Phillips. The design feels both stylish and tactile, Tarantino's preference for real sets, cars and props over CGI environments gives the film's setting weight and character which perfectly captures the feeling of Hollywood in this era. Edited by Fred Raskin the film clocks in at 161 minutes. It doesn't strictly follow a traditional three act structure and often indulges in scenes which do little to advance the plot or characters, but despite the slower pace it is consistently entertaining. 

The acting on display is all excellent as you would expect from such an A-list cast. DiCaprio brings a lot of charisma to a mean and self-obsessive alcoholic. Pitt manages to make his character likeable despite being lazy and violent with a questionable past. If those characters show the fall of the Golden Age of Cinema Margot Robbie in her small role as Sharon Tate represents a more innocent and romanticised past for Hollywood, something authentically optimistic. These characters have little in the way of character growth and Tarantino avoids making judgement on their motivations and actions thus the film functions more as a well-crafted snapshot of old Hollywood and is less a story about characters or theme. 
 
The film will not be to everyone's taste, it is long and slow paced, it doesn't have a typical protagonist versus antagonist dynamic, and it doesn't offer satisfying character arcs. There is also the trade-mark Tarantino violence which is always a point of contention for audiences. But it is a highly entertaining, expertly crafted unique film that draws you into its world with a great sense of atmosphere and attitude.

Great acting from Pitt and DiCaprio as usual, and great production design, but the rest is Tarantino up to his usual overblown "vision" that has minimal narrative structure. At least five times in the film I thought, "Okay, here we are again at a new starting place," and because of that, it's not very interesting, but it's enough fun to barely get a passing grade, mainly because of the aforementioned actors, who make the most of his trademark good dialogue. You definitely cannot accuse Tarantino of writing bad dialogue, and he's a great director technically, but there's little thematic depth. However, the end does do a bit to redeem this otherwise lackluster, mostly style affair.

It's shot well, has the signature Tarantino soundtrack filled with classic throwbacks, and the climactic bloody showdown in Dalton's house against the Manson members was decently entertaining to watch, but aside from that this entire movie was a bit of a let down.  I liked the somewhat love letter to classic Hollywood cinema that's spread throughout the movie via iconic actors and characters from the past as well as the impressive re-creation of the 60's time period. Once Upon a Time In Hollywood, is a wonderfully crafted film. Quentin Tarantino has a gift and a clear passion for crafting each of the worlds presented in all of his films, and this movie is no exception. Each scene is expertly shot and acted in ways only many movies could dream of. Brad Pitt, and Leonardo DiCaprio give excellent performances as the movies two leads, and I was rooting for them throughout, their chemistry and charisma in the film is great, and they left me smiling all the way through. Margot Robbie also shines in this film as Sharon Tate. I have only ever had the chance to see her as Harley Quinn, so seeing her play a different role, and doing it so well was a real treat for me, as she really is a very talented actress. This movie is surprisingly funnier than I expected, Tarantino really does have a gift for blending drama, and dark humor masterfully, and I was enthralled at the way that I found humor even in moments where any other film would never dream of going in that direction with that topic or tone. I loved how this film was an entire love letter to Hollywood and its golden age, and I enjoyed picking out each iteration of Easter Egg for both the history of Hollywood, as well as a few I found referencing the careers of some of the films actors as well. I don't have much that I disliked about this movie, they are nitpicks at best, and I am sure that I am in the minority on them which is fine, these are just my opinions. The one that I do have is simply that I felt that at one point in the movie they play up a certain character that Brad Pitt spends some time with as more important than they appear to be later on in the film. I felt that they should have played this up a bit more and made them a part of the climax later on in the movie. All in all take what I say with a grain of salt, this is just a minor nitpick after all, and in the the long run does not diminish how awesome this movie truly is! I give Once Upon a Time In Hollywood a 9.5/10!

Tarantino shows no signs of losing his touch. Unlike his other films, "Once Upon a Time … in Hollywood" is more of a relaxed hangout comedy that sentimentally pays respect to the Hollywood that sparked Quentin's dreams and aspirations. The film is a nostalgic farrago rather than a period drama of the likes of "Basterds," "Django," or "The Hateful Eight."

The film does lack tension compared to other Tarantino films, but that is not the case during the sprawling sequence in which Cliff visits the Spahn Ranch. In terms of danger and suspense, this scene is reminiscent of the pawn shop ordeal in "Pulp Fiction." 

One of the most moving scenes in the film belongs solely to Tate and is largely made possible due to Robbie's speechless performance. Tate attends a sparsely populated matinee to see herself in "The Wrecking Crew." The onscreen footage of the real-life Sharon Tate, coupled with Robbie watching wondrously, makes this realization of a dream even more poignant.

Considering its two-hour, forty-one minute runtime, the film gets off to a slow start in the first act and meanders during the second, but it all pays off in the end. Very much like the Westerns it imitates, the film gets better as it drags along, ultimately reaching its satisfying culmination. Even though "Once Upon a Time … in Hollywood" is largely a deviation from other Tarantino revenge flicks, its denouement is just as vengefully gratifying.

Once Upon a Time in Hollywood is almost a good film. I'd be lying if I said I wasn't entertained while watching it. Brad Pitt and Leonardo DiCaprio are a joy to watch on screen, but I never want to see this movie again and I am so glad Tarantino didn't win anything for it. And it's all because of that ending.

The weird fanfic-y turn it takes at the end is completely unconnected from the main story of the plot and as a result feels incomplete as a climax. You don't get any resolution for the arcs of Rick Dalton or Cliff Boone, the main characters of the story. Instead you get a "What If" scenario where all of a sudden our protagonist turn into action heroes and then it's just over. I don't have a problem with them stopping the Manson Family, as that could've lead somewhere interesting in theory. However, it should've happened in the second act so we could see how it actually impacts their careers and reputations. Our characters aren't changed by it and the world of the movie isn't changed by it either. It changed our world, but since we can't actually bring Sharon Tate back from the grave and prevent Roman Polanski from become a creepy pedophile, then it really doesn't accomplish anything. 

In Inglorious Bastards, which also does the revisionist history thing, the entire film is built around these guys hunting and killing Nazis, so when they kill Hitler, It's a satisfying conclusion. The Manson Family are there as a subplot and a not very deep one at that. The movie is about the two being washed up Hollywood performers living unfulfilled lives and in the end, that doesn't change. Rick getting invited into the Tate-Polanski House at the end doesn't actually mean anything. Maybe Rick Dalton will one day star in Chinatown, but we have no way of knowing that. As far as we know, they're still miserable losers and will continue to be after the events of August 9, 1969.

When this near 3 hour movie just abruptly ends, you can't help but feel cheated by all the time it wastes. Sharon Tate did not need to be a character in this movie. None of her scenes are important and it's just done as a misdirection to the audience. We all know what happens to her with the Manson Family in our timeline, so it's meant to work as dramatic irony to build tension for when she gets killed, but that doesn't happen, so it ends up being pointless.

Things that are excusable in the moment become unforgivable in hindsight. We get a lot of flashbacks and fake movie scenes that don't really contribute anything to the plot. I get that Tarantino just wanted to jerk himself off and do a bunch of fun skits, but when it doesn't build to anything and just pads the length of an already over-long movie, then they should be left on the cutting room floor. I liked a few of these scenes, even though they all went on way too long, but I would've rather had that time be used to focus on something relevant instead of just being a love letter to old movies and tv. And why did we have so many scenes of Brad Pitt driving his car? I get it, people drive a lot in LA and you get to see some recognizable visuals, but that doesn't mean I want to see it. There must've been 10 minutes at least of Brad Pitt driving his car.

Overall, I think I feel cheated by this movie. Quinten Tarantino has made some great films over the years (Djanjo Unchained is one of my all-time favorites), but this is a definite miss. There were bits I liked. I absolutely loved Rick Dalton, which is why the finale pisses me off so much. It's because I liked the movie that I hate it. Does that make sense? If it doesn't, then you know exactly how I feel about the creative decisions in this movie. It's the perfect example of a director not being told "No". It's easily one of Tarantino's worst films, as it truly goes for style over substance. It's meandering, bloated, sensationalist, and not nearly as clever as it thinks it is. Once Upon a Time in Hollywood is every bad thing critics say about Tarantino and it deserves to be left in the past

The cinematography was a big plus, as it made the film come across as very genuine.  Leo, as usual, kills it in this role as an aging Hollywood star.  I didn't think Pitt deserved an Oscar for his role, but he was very entertaining.  It's a fun movie that puts a whole new spin on how the Manson murders turned out in another dimension.  I would definitely recommend this film, but not before all of his other classics.

Tarantino is a brilliant storyteller but this is not his best. It's basically an alternate reality story that follows a fading star and his stunt double buddy for a little too long (over two hours) until, in a moment of self-defense, they suddenly wind up preventing the Manson murders in the most grizzly way possible. Not knowing much about the Manson murders I fell like I missed out on some of the build up. Moments that were supposed to be tense were just puzzling. For instance, I love Bruce Dern but his cameo struck me as just odd. The movie has very little violence until the end, when the light drama suddenly shifts into an over-the-top gore fest that is cartoonishly gruesome and out of tone from the rest of the movie. Tarantino spends two hours weaving a tapestry and then finishes by splattering the whole thing with blood and lighting it on fire. For me the payoff wasn't worth the ride.

I appreciated the stylized costumes and settings of the film, and I think that DiCaprio and Pitt had a dynamic relationship on screen. However, the story as a whole did not make sense to me. While I fully admit that I didn't watch this with my full attention, the plot seemed too diffuse in the first 2 hours to justify the final 30 minutes of intensity. When I look back and try to explain the movie, it seems like the two are entirely separate plots. Perhaps a closer rewatch would explain it, or maybe I'm missing the point entirely.

There are certain filmmakers that settle into their distinct style more and more with each film. Quentin Tarantino is among that group. Tarantino has also reached the same stature in the film community that Stephen King has in the literary world: for better or worse, he's too successful to be edited down. Indeed, his latest film might also be his most "Tarantino" film since Pulp Fiction. Once Upon a in Time…in Hollywood, a sprawling but not quite epic tour through Los Angeles in 1969 that crosses paths with Bruce Lee, the Manson Family, and Sharon Tate, indulges in long, two-character conversations, pop culture references (both obvious and subtle), wall to wall pop music, flashbacks, insert shots and closeups, barefoot women, an unnecessary narrator, cameos from actors from previous films, and, of course, some bloody, bloody violence. There's also an emotional maturity that we haven't seen since Jackie Brown.

I left the theater uncertain whether I liked the picture or not, but by the time I got to my car I knew for sure that I had just seen the most interesting and challenging film by Tarantino in years. I also knew I had seen one of the best films of 2019. Tarantino always manages to surprise us, even when his films are set around historical events.

Leonardo DiCaprio stars as Rick Dalton, a former TV cowboy who can now only land roles playing the villain of the week on other shows (many of them, Green Hornet, The F.B.I, Lancer, are real shows). A Hollywood agent (Al Pacino in a small but well-played part) offers Rick a second chance as a leading man in Italian spaghetti westerns. Rick takes this as proof that he's a has-been. DiCaprio does the best acting of his career as the washed-up TV cowboy, especially in the scenes of him on the set of the TV western, Lancer. In a wonderfully written, beautifully performed scene between Rick and a child actress DiCaprio expresses vulnerability in a way he never has with any character. 10-year-old Julia Butters proves to be a worthy scene partner for DiCaprio (which is no surprise if you've seen her steal every scene on the TV show American Housewife).

Brad Pitt plays Cliff Booth, Rick's stuntman, driver, handyman, and only friend. If Rick is washed up, Cliff is un-hirable. He may, or may not, have killed his wife and gotten away with it (Tarantino shows us a brief ambiguous flashback) which, along with his irresponsible behavior on set, doesn't endear him to stunt coordinators. Pitt's performance is not exactly showy, but it is pronounced. Cliff is a character with no self-illusions; he has an easy confidence and Pitt is very comfortable in the role. It's not his most challenging performance but it is one of his most memorable.

Margot Robbie plays the beautiful rising star Sharon Tate. She and her husband Roman Polanski, the hottest director in Hollywood, have just moved in next door to Rick. The few scenes that follow Tate as she goes about her day play more like distant observations that idolize her rather than moments that show us an inner life or build her up as a character. Robbie doesn't have many lines but she still brings her enchanting screen presence to the role, which in this case is all that is required.            

Once Upon a Time...in Hollywood has a fun, brilliant energy. Since you are essentially just hanging out with Rick and Cliff as they go about their days there is a slight episodic feel as the movie goes on but the pacing is smooth and steady. In each scene you'll find Tarantino's signature sharp dialogue and interesting, colorful characters, both fictional and fictionalized. A long scene that places Cliff at the Spahn Movie Ranch, home of the Manson Family, is the most tense and frightening scene Tarantino has ever done. It's a Hitchcockian scene bursting with suspense. The most entertaining scene in the entire movie is a long flashback to Cliff's fight with Bruce Lee. This scene has caused a lot of controversy (Lee's family has called in disrespectful) because it suggests that Cliff, a stuntman with no training, could have possibly won in a fight with Bruce Lee. I don't think the scene pokes fun at Lee; if anything, Lee getting thrown without padding into a car door so hard it leaves a crater and then just shaking it off a moment later makes this Bruce Lee look pretty badass. It's also a delight to watch Mike Moh's great performance as the larger than life Bruce Lee.


The Hollywood of this movie feels like a very lived-in world. Nothing feels completely brand new. The sets of TV shows are deglamorized work places. Everything from the hip and not so hip clothing to the cars to the homes feel like the people in this movie have actually been using them. Little details like radio commercials for movies, old TV commercials, movie posters, and billboards all add up to a total immersion in this time period. It's this immersive, authentic feel that is at odds with the film's final act, the night of the Sharon Tate and her houseguest's murder. Tarantino, never one to let a story go where you think, does something unexpected which, honestly, I should have seen coming. It's right there in the title, "Once Upon a Time…" Despite all of the intricate details, it seems this film is a fantasy after all. 

The final act won't work for everyone, there's also plenty in the rest of the movie that won't work for everyone (like having one of the leads be a potential murderer). There have been many, many discussions and arguments about nearly everything in this movie; it's rare that we get a film that sparks such interest and conversations. Tarantino has said that he plans to retire after his next movie. I'm skeptical of such declarations from any filmmaker. If true, his penultimate film provides great entertainment and plenty for us to ponder. It also has my expectations high for his supposed final film.

Definitely not a film for everyone. The slow shots and plentiful storylines build up excitement for the very Quentin Tarantino-like ending, which in some cases makes the rest of the movie worth it. Once Upon a Time in Hollywood is exquisite, and portrays the golden age of film in a way that pleases [almost] everyone.

Okay, let's talk about Once Upon A Time In Hollywood, the ninth film in the career of the genius Quentin Tarantino and probably his penultimate. Here he brings a very interesting hollywood setting in the late 60's. Right at the beginning of the film you can already imagine what the story will be, as it portrays the murder of Sharon Tate, which shook everyone at the time. Quentin Tarantino's direction and script remain brilliant and extremely authoritative. We can not fail to mention the high point of this work, the performances, Leonardo DiCaprio is impeccable, Margot Robbie is fantastic, but who manages to surprise more is Brad Pitt, who probably did the best job of his career, I believe that Brad's only performance who can go head to head with this is his role in Inglorious Basterds. We also have a brief appearance by Al Pacino, which is a pleasant surprise. The soundtrack is very well done and one of the best of the year. To conclude, I believe that this is not the best film of Tarantino's career, films like Django Unchained, Pulp Fiction and Reservoir Dogs present more complete elements, but Once Upon A Time In Hollywood is an excellent work of direction, script, acting and soundtrack sonorous.

I'm very happy that this was Tarantino's last film. It was a little bit on the nose with a farewell movie and there's a lot of Tarantino's ego written all over the film. The acting was great but some of the scenes were a little bit stretched out and not believable. This movie encompassed all the things that got Tarantino into film making but it also wasn't as interesting as his interests told in separate solid movies. Production was pretty spot on. And although I said that acting was really good, I felt like the movie could have used lesser known actors. I personally love a star studded film but this one just felt more like a publicity/ marketing thing rather than the right person for the role.

Boring movie. Whenever I hear of a new upcoming Tarantino film I am struct with excitement in anticipation. After all, many of his past films have been some of my favorites of all time (Hateful Eight, Django, and Reservoir Dogs). With this said, I could not have been more disappointed with 'Once Upon a Time in Hollywood'. There were several points during the film when my friends asked if we could leave. I, hoping the film would pick up in pace after the first hour, assured them to stay. The film did not. Completely different from his previous films, this movie did not maintain my attention due to its slow pace and lack of an interesting story line. The most interesting part of the film (as many others have pointed out) was the ending, but even that was not enough to save the film. The pros would be the outstanding performances from Pitt and DiCaprio. Overall, if the film had a more interesting plot then I would have been more eager to give it a solid rating. I will not be adding this movie to my list.

There's not a scene with Leo that he doesn't own. Q.T.'s writing and character take on Rick Dalton paved DiCaprio's way to an Oscar nomination while providing one of the best roles he's had in years. Nonetheless, Once Upon a Time...In Hollywood will leave you in awe of acting, writing, and cinematography perfection, while also urging you to give yourself a history lesson on the haunting true story that was avoided.

Quentin's latest is, in many ways, quintessentially Tarantino. It's a film made by a zealous cinemaphile, and here we can see, as we can in all his movies, his passion for the craft. Tarantino tells the story in his own idiosyncratic way and at his own measured pace.

The film hops between different plot strands in a narrative that's fascinating, if slow - but never sluggish, thanks to the lively soundtrack and the actors' pep. Many scenes feel bloated, but the detail in those scenes does arguably bear a significance for the viewer in comprehending the film's philosophy. But if you go into the cinema knowing nothing at all about the Tate-LaBianca murders, which much of the younger demographic may well do, then it's hard to make sense of the film's denouement. Of course, even if the case, there's still plenty to enjoy. Once Upon a Time... does feature some comedy gold moments - Cliff Booth's anecdote of his sparring contest with Bruce Lee, in particular. But familiarity with Golden Age movies and their stars, and recognising pop culture references, are a prerequisite for the audience accessing a lot of the humour. For this reason, some of the gags don't land. 

Despite not so much going on plot-wise for large segments of the film, there's tonnes going on under the surface. I exhausted myself sifting through the plethora of Golden Age references: names dropped in conversation, pictures of bygone actors on movie posters, contemporary events voiced over car radio. I felt as though the more I noticed, the more context I had for the movie. 

There are easy things to appreciate in Once Upon a Time.... There's a fantastic soundtrack featuring, among others, Simon & Garfunkel and Deep Purple. Tarantino has a knack for choosing the right songs for the right moments. California Dreamin', beautifully sung by Jose Feliciano, plays over a peaceful montage which includes the three narrative threads. It's a moment of peace and of reflection, before the film descends into violence. There are gorgeous shots, too, many of the most satisfying being those tracking shots following cars. Tarantino and his film crew absolutely capture the zeitgeist of 1960s Hollywood.    

The slow burner terminates in a very violent final act, shocking in not just its brutality but also in the manner it concludes the narrative. I'll say little else on this so to not give away the ending. But after witnessing the graphic violence towards the movies end, one realises just how little violence there has been in the movie up to this point (well, for a Tarantino picture anyway...). 

The hasty final act sits awkwardly against the otherwise inflated run-time, and as a consequence one sits wondering at the film's conclusion if it was worth it. The film's extremely heavy reliance on the audience having prior knowledge of the Tate murders is also irritating. Once Upon a Time in Hollywood is, in my opinion, smug and self-indulgent - and unapologetically so. In the end it probably comes down to whether or not we're happy to indulge Tarantino.

Excellent soundtrack, as always, cinematography and late 60s Hollywood revival. However, the script doesn't say much. After all, it's a Quentin Tarantino's film.

The biggest fear about making a film like Once Upon a Time in Hollywood is to not get the period thing right- and if the dynamics of the era of cinema is not done well, the entire film falls short of its ambition and doesn't quiet soar. But that's just what the film deeply delves into. The chemistry of Brad Pitt and Leonardo DeCaprio is never less than enchanting. This is an audaciously fascinating and surprisingly slick and melancholic film that's thrillingly unrestrained and the most wildly entertaining English film of the year. It's exploration of friendships only adds to the overall joy. If only the storytelling was less inert and more compact, Quentin Tarantino might have promised a flawless feature. But that doesn't tell you this, "The film is unmissable!" And it's unapologetic. It's incredible. It'd be remembered. That'd be all.
