I barely sat through an hour of this film, I don't know where all these good reviews are coming from, but to all these people giving this movie 4 stars and up, you need to get your head examined if you call this piece of drivel "entertainment" (in fact giving this movie more than 1 star is being incredibly generous - I'd give this film zero if I could). If the dialogue doesn't make you sleep, the slow pace of this picture certainly would (I kept waiting and waiting for this movie to "get to the point" of something, but alas, nothing happened - I only managed to sit through 1 hour and 17 minutes of this dreadful tripe of a movie - if you managed more than that, I take my hat off to you). How this movie has been nominated for best picture is a mystery to me, as I've said before, if you gave this movie more than 1 star, you probably should get your head examined. My final verdict, zero stars, but since I can't give it a zero, I'm forced to give it a half-star (something that this movie sure as hell doesn't deserve!)

Once Upon a Time is a pleasing blend of the trappings of new Tarantino; pulpy voiceovers that come out of nowhere to explain something, more standard linear storytelling, revisionist history. And it also has the punch and wit of early Tarantino; the restrained and yet sumptuously enigmatic camera-work of something like Jackie Brown, and the delve back into the friendship of fraudulent men such as in Reservoir Dogs.

But unlike all of those movies, it seems as if Once Upon a Time is actually concerned with telling a nice story, a story with relatable and sympathetic characters, about growth, and not just in an acerbically witty banterous kind of way. I found DiCaprio gave my favourite performance of his, something sweet and weak and broken and yet also talented, magical and chewed up by the Hollywood system; watching him grow and act and emote is a really exciting cornerstone of this movie.

Despite its protracted and masturbatory scenes towards the middle, they are never anything less than magnetic, potent and brisk. And as the film moves through many sub-genres, it's evident that Tarantino's love of cinema has allowed him to make a mash-up of Hollywood great scenes; the cult horror moments of the Ranch, the pitch perfect Italian cinema section, the incredible tension of the Manson alumni scenes, the french new wave gaze of Tarantino's camera on Margot Robbie's Sharon Tate, now a figure of myth. 

I really enjoyed it, it was the most evolved of Tarantino's recent films; fun and unique but more restrained and much warmer and more personable. As a love letter should be. I liked that the relationships seemed genuine, I loved the scene where the two buds watch the show together, and the film as a whole constantly surprised me.

Once Upon a Time feels like Tarantino's most personal film and yet also like his transition into another medium; Once Upon feels much more novelistic. The ending is absurd and strangely welcome given knowledge of the real world events, it's wish fulfilment of the highest order, but after falling in love with these characters, and acknowledging how much bloodhsed, dashed potential, and bollocks there is in the world, it's nice to see something more like Sorkin's take on The White House in the West Wing; it's OK to feel powerless and use art to understand and sometimes rewrite some of the world's tragedies.

I really enjoyed the first two hours of this movie. I thought it was my favourite Tarantino up until that point. I love the duo of DiCaprio and Pitt as they really give a great depiction of a new angle of hollywood. The last half hour however was where the film really came apart for me. Tarantino opts for a lazy time jump that offers nothing to the plot except give an excuse for the final action scene to occur. This final climax of the movie is the most forced action scene I have ever seen. I know Tarantino is infamous for gratuitous violence and all but usually it serves a purpose to the plot. Here it serves no purpose and it honestly feels like Tarantino felt obliged to add it to satisfy his fans. The whole ending is trying to set up a subversion of the Manson murders which just feels so tacked on to the rest of the film that has been, up to that point, a subtle character study of an actor falling out of fame. Furthermore, Margot Robbie is entirely wasted in this film. In fact the marketing is completely misleading because she literally does not influence the plot until the very very last shot of the film. None of her scenes have a message or a statement either, they all feel like an excuse to introduce her character so that they can subvert the conclusion at the end. It was such a fantastic film up until the conclusion for me where it really shot itself in the foot.

I absolutely loved this film. I grew up in this era and am quite aware of what was happening in Hollywood then. It was about 1969, TV character actor Rick Dalton star of the TV show "Bounty Law" his stunt double Clint Booth, a wife murderer and their relationship as actor and stunt double. 
Quentin wrote the greatest dialogue and I got everything he was doing here. It's another true mixes fiction film he puts out, when you see that Rick Dalton lives next door to Roman Polanski and Sharon Tate. Filmed  on the same ranch where Charles Manson's "family" lived.
I'm just going to mention a couple scenes as not wanting to spoil it. 1969 was a very scary year to live in California, the Manson murders were gruesome and those killed suffered. Here again Quentin gives us what we want justice to the killings, so he mixes part of what really happened and what is fiction. 
Brad Pitt is so hilariously good in this, He hardly has dialogues but everything with Brad is acting with saying very little. Check out the scene when Cliff Booth fights Bruce Lee , especially funny. 
One more scene, Al Pacino at his funniest game a sleazy producer Mr. Schwarz who is interested in Rick Dalton (Leo DiCaprio) watches all his movies and TV shows in a binge watching. Schwarz (who Dalton called Schwartz) Pacino tells him it's not Schwartz but Schwarz. He describes what he likes in every clip the studio  sends him, especially funny is when Schwarz tells Dalton that jokers sent this over cinemascope of him on "Hullabaloo" complete with cheesy cheerleader girls dancing around him, with Dalton (Leo) singing the song "The Green Door" Leo cannot sing Quentin knew it and forced DiCaprio to do it, he was so awful it was hilariously done.
If you were the last of the baby boomers you will notice all the hidden jokes in this film. I'd say that 16 and over is all right with this film and I think they would enjoy it too. This is not the story of Charles Manson, he has only one scene it's more about Cliff Booth and Rick Dalton. Great movie, you can watch it over and find the funny parts you missed first time. It is hardly bloody at all.

A very anticipated film, probably second after "Joker". Said to be Tarantino's last, or next to last, movie and he has put together one heck of a cast as usual. This is the based on a true story as it takes place the monts and years ahead of Shannon Tate's gruesome murder. This is kind of the directors version of it, as I see it. It's not excact, it's far of the reality actually, but the base is there.

Rick Dalton (DiCaprio) is a falling TV-star, trying to score some movie roles in Hollywood. He lives there with his friend and body double Cliff (Brad Pitt). They share some moments on set but we also se them from the perspectives of there separate lives. Rick's neighbors are Polanski and his beautiful wife, Sharon (Margot Robbie). She is also in the business and if you know the tragic story of her, you kind of know her deal in this film.

I like the way the film develops. It looks great, it's god those great scenes and script - some wonderful lines. It's slick and very cool - all the way. It's so typical Tarrentino that any given scene will give away that he is the man behind it. Filled with references and a score that have so many gems, many of them sampled in songs of my own personal liking. Dakota Fanning, Luke Perry, Al Pacino, Bruce Dern are also in this film. Quite some cast, huh?

So, there is not much wrong here. I like the retelling of the story and it's a vivid, fun ride. It has those ultra violent scenes to lift it and make it even more entertaining and it has few loose threds and no stupid stuff. This is very entertaining. It's long, but never flat. I like it a whole lot, and I find it to be the directors best flick since the "Kill Bill" era.

: Director: Quentin Tarantino Writer: Quentin Tarantino Starring: Leonardo DiCaprio, Brad Pitt, Margot Robbie, Emile Hirsch, Margaret Qualley, Timothy Olyphant, Al Pacino Narrator: Kurt Russell A bold preamble flashes up on screen announcing Quentin Tarantino's ninth film. It's a stark reminder that Tarantino is competing with his own legacy. Can anything truly match the sheer brilliance of Reservoir Dogs and Pulp Fiction? First cuts are often the deepest, but Once Upon a Time in Hollywood comfortably reaches the bar set so unreasonably high.

His customary attention to detail is forensic as 35mm film is used to frame a story set in 1969; exactly what have been in use at the time. Fictional characters are cleverly set against true events as they mingle with real people in a concurrent storyline.

Rick Dalton (Leonardo DiCaprio) is a jobbing TV actor who fears the big movie roles have passed him by. He is consoled by Bounty Law; a long running Western where he plays the grizzled bad guy. Faithful wingman Cliff Booth (Brad Pitt) is Rick's stunt double, best friend and confidante. Back in Beverley Hills Rick has new neighbours. Impossibly beautiful actress Sharon Tate (Margot Robbie) has moved in with husband Roman Polanski. Rick is excited by the prospect and could be one pool party away from starring in a Polanski movie. If only he could actually meet them. Meanwhile, producer Harvey Schwarz (Al Pacino) is convinced he can reignite Rick's career with a spaghetti western. Interestingly, the Manson clan is hardly shown in the movie. I actually like this choice, because it left a lingering thought that perhaps Manson was a danger at all times, and didn't play to the audience the way we thought it would. It wasn't a story about the Manson murders. Manson just happened to be going on at the time Dalton and Booth were having their struggles, and it intersected.

There are many pleasures to be found in "Once Upon a Time in Hollywood," but Tarantino's interest in replicating Los Angeles in 1969 is worth the price of admission alone. It's enough to find period cars and costumes, but Tarantino goes above and beyond, filling backgrounds with detailed signage and theater marquees, redressed buildings, and packing the radio with advertisements and glorious rock hits to set the mood. Tech credits are downright miraculous, securing the time machine nature of the feature, with Tarantino as much in love with his layered frames as he is with the characters, working diligently to take away the modern world. There's enough going on around the action in "Once Upon a Time in Hollywood" to warrant multiple viewings, just to see the hospital corners Tarantino achieves when resurrecting the end of an era. Very impressive .

DiCaprio proves to be such a perfect choice for Dalton that one can't really imagine anyone else in the part. It's one of his best performances, although he's arguably topped by a fantastic Pitt, that reminds viewers how wonderful he can be in the right material.

It's a glorious fusion of genres; part western, buddy movie and homage to popular culture in the 1960s. Stylish and visually stunning, it bears the classic hallmarks of a Tarantino film. Maddening tangents, delightful cameos and set pieces all provide a compulsive mixture. The cinematography, the writing, the casting, the soundtrack, all flawless. This is a superior film and sits comfortably in my top three Tarantino films. 10/10

For some reason movie makers want to relive the 70's (or very late 60's in this case), which if you lived it back then was one of the worst decades to be around, except for maybe the Bicentennial celebrations.  The 70's gave us a lost war, high gas prices, runaway inflation, disco and Jimmy Carter.  So you can see why most of America does not want to see bell-bottom wearing characters in loud print shirts even to this day.  The 70's was so bad, that most people in the 80's adamantly eschewed anything to do with the prior decade.  As with the Irishman, this movie Once Upon A Time in Hollywood, is outdated, and I had little care to revisit the events of those August nights.  perhaps something more current would have been a good topic?  Or at least something not 50 years ago.  Plus, this rendition was not only boring through the first two hours, but most of the winding plot had little to do with character development, other than to say, this guy is a stuntman, and this guy is a method actor.  And why did we have to watch Sharon Tate going to a theater to watch her own movie.  Who cares?  Perhaps some comic or anecdotal writing during this two hour window would have made sense?  Maybe next film.  At the end the explanation of the movie title is revealed, although a bit muddled for my taste.  Also, and just a note here for the producer, if a character is in a swimming pool getting flamethrower roasted, perhaps it would be sensible to go under the water, instead of just screaming loudly and being burned to a crisp.  In fact, that is a good lesson for any of us.  If you are on fire (even if you are not in a pool) please find some water nearby to douse yourself.  Or baking powder, if it is a grease fire.  Just sayin.  It seems to me that, like The Irishman, this movie was not well thought out, and that the writer/producer/director was simply relying on us to watch this film because Leo and Brad were in it.  So shame on us, I guess.  Overall, I believe if you are going to make a movie about Hollywood, and all the foibles that go with Hollywood, it should at least have some edge in it, and some tongue in cheek comedy,  like The Player, or The Big Picture.
The acting was well done but there was truly no real plot. It was a meandering 2 1/2 hour film that goes no where.

I am a huge fan of Quentin Tarantino, with ‘The Hateful Eight' being my favorite movie he's made. This film is an interesting ride I gotta say. I enjoy his way of splicing scenes together, and his style of not wanting to just tell the viewer, but to show them as well. I'm a sucker for his random interstitials that bring more context and backstory to the characters. They always present themselves to be context clues for the viewer, but conclude to be vital to the story in the end. The last act of the movie presented so many unexpected events, and was very over the top. I really appreciate this about Quentin Tarantino because he does this in every one of his films, just because he can. Brad Pitt did a great job, and Leonardo DeCaprio obviously killed it, showing time and time again what an amazing actor he is. I like the film overall and will be thinking about Once Upon a Time in Hollywood for a while.

Once Upon a Time... in Hollywood offers an interesting look back on Hollywood in the 60s. Quinton Tarantino returns to direct this somewhat comedic look on the Charles Manson that subverts your expectations. It's a great, fun movie, with great acting (Especially by Brad Pitt.) My largest complaint is that while it may look great, and it may give the audience a precise look at Hollywood in the 60s, it lacks in a great story. It had a fairly basic story, but, it felt jumbled and thrown together. Nevertheless, it was a great movie and I'd definitely recommend it.

You can also argue a few characters are essentially irrelevant, like Bruce Lee, and Margot Robbie's character didn't get to do much. The artistic nature, Cliff Booth, and ending scenes are where it shines.

10/10  Tarantino dials it back a little with Once Upon a Time in Hollywood, which is a surprisingly relaxed and dramatic experience (although he makes up for it in the extremely bizarre, but awesome climax). DiCaprio and (especially) Pitt are absolutely fantastic as a depressed actor and a laid-back stuntman, and Margot Robbie is extremely likable as Sharon Tate. There are also plenty of great bit roles throughout, featuring the likes of Al Pacino, Kurt Russell, Margaret Qualley, Timothy Olyphant, etc. The cinematography and scene transitions are beautiful, as well as Tarantino's overall direction. Finally, the soundtrack is pretty catchy without being distracting. In sum, it's Quentin Tarantino's most nature project yet, and is well worth watching.

My favorite film of 2019. A time-machine de force that magnificently captures the charm, neon glow and subversive seediness of Hollywood at a time when the 60s vision of peace and love was fading into disappointment, while offering a surreal, fable-like ending that erases at least one of humankind's great horrors. Some might call it revisionist-history revenge. But I would risk saying that it provides a flush bulb of hopeful existentialism for an uneasy era where chaos, fear and confusion threaten to rip through the polished shine of 21st century life. Brad Pitt's performance is an absolute treat. One of Tarantino's best.

I saw this movie with my dad on the opening weekend. Walking out, we both said, "meh, boring!". I originally expected a "Tarantino-esque" action packed film such as "Inglourious Basterds" or "Django Unchained", and this film just didn't do it for me then. A few later, once the film came out for rent, I decided to give it a second chance, duly based on all the Oscar buzz it was getting. Something clicked the second time around, because the film hit me so much harder. Yes, it's long, with a LOT of drawn out acting scenes, but there's something completely different to appreciate about this film that differs from Tarantino's prior work. It's the performances and specific traits presented by the film's two leads. The story's fantastic, and the last 20 minutes of the film are some of my favorite moments in a movie, but the forced vulnerability of Leonardo DiCaprio's "Rick Dalton", combined with the nonchalant humor of Brad Pitt's "Cliff Booth" make for the greatest movie duo I can think of. Their performances electrify every problem with this film, enhancing it by so much, making everything that much better.

I enjoyed Quentin Tarantino's rendition of his love affair with the hollywood industry of the late 1960's and 1970's. It was over the top bizarre at times throughout, but for Tarantino, this means normal fare. Brad Pitt did what I thought was a well acted job playing a back-up stuntman to the Leo's aging character. Margo Robby was fine. The actors felt too loose at times. I'm not sure if it was them having so much fun during the process, not focused or if this was a deliberate design by Tarantino; probably the latter right?  The film had great production design and the writing I thought was tremendous. The problem for me was the length. You felt it. It was just way too unnecessarily long. Tarantino is a unique writing, iconic genius, but someone needs to tell him in his ear and whisper "cut" a little more often. The pace was too slow and not tight enough. Editing wasn't the strongest here. The music was phenomenal.  Side note* I wrote a review 3 weeks ago. Clearly, it did not save.

Once upon a time in Hollywood, isn't the sort of movie your going to brain picking your mind for weeks about and endlessly desperate for answers. No it was a more laid back approach from Tarantino, this film focusing on fictional actor Rick Dalton (Leonardo DiCaprio) who isn't the same actor he used to be, due to this he is facing a dilemma in the film industry. Not to forget his stunt double Cliff Booth, (Brad Pitt) is very supportive of his old buddy and that was a great duo and relationship to watch on screen. Leo's lead role was different to his usual, that's for sure. It was actually a pleasant surprise to watch Leo DiCaprio play a less serious character for once. He was was actually really amusing at times. This film in my opinion is a great film and has been widely referred to as Tarantino's ‘Crown Jewell' or his ‘love letter to Hollywood' I believe the film is a metaphor for the current stage their careers that Leo and Quentin are currently in. They are both middle aged artists who have more than likely seen their heyday already, now they are more than likely going to decline and pave way for future film makers to actors. So when you look deeper into the artistic ways Tarantino expresses himself through film, you can't help but be impressed. Overall In my opinion it ranks somewhere in the bottom half in my favourite Tarantino movies, however it was beautifully produced and was great fun from start to finish.

Beautiful cinematography, skilled acting, and engaging themes aren't enough to save this frustrating script. Brad Pitt's character is the quintessence of a Gary Stu with no arc at all. There is a narrator that joins us halfway through the film and only sticks around for about twenty minutes. The climax may be grandiose, typical of its director, but the successes of the protagonists aren't won by anything they've come to learn throughout the story, which is an indispensable part of telling a story. Worst of all, this movie assumes that just because we know about the Manson murderers, it can gloss over those characters in its narrative, which is nothing short of lazy writing that makes for an unsatisfying story, to my great disappointment.

This movie is a wonderful tribute to the final stage of Golden Age Hollywood. Although there are some pacing issues, the brilliant acting (especially from Pitt), as well as the 100% Tarantinoesque screenplay, and much more, combine to make a Tarantino movie which - yes, here it comes - seems to have something for everyone. Though, I must warn you about the final 15 minutes of the film. That's when what we would call "classic Tarantino" really kicks in!

I liked this movie a lot. Not my favorite Tarantino movie, but it’s definitely in a class all on its own. I went into thinking with the Sharon Tate murders as a backdrop, this wasn’t going to end well. Oh, the end was bloody, but not at all what I was thinking. Brad Pitt and Leonardo DiCaprio were outstanding. Did Leo overact in some scenes? Yes. But that was the point. He was playing an C-list actor. Pitt was amazing. The movie was long, but to tell the multiple stories, it had to take some time. Finally, Pitt and the dog, Randy, were a deadly comedy team in its own right.

The movie is a great watch as it perfectly represents a fantasy like hollywood while still maintaining a consistent interest all the way through. The symbolism of rick dalton a man stuck in time who wants to stay in the fantasy land meeting sharon tate after not dying her horrific murder that ended the 60s is just fantastic. Even the controversial bruce lee representation had a purpose to further establish who cliff is as a member of Hollywood at the time. The POV of cliff was on bruce Lee a successful asian man who practically shunned hollywood and its portrayal of toughness and power. Cliff was an all American stunt man who saw things through his filter. Clearly an antihero even being framed as his wife's murderer you still connect with him on a human level. Also let's not forget that the flashback may not even be a flashback at all but a day dream as it's up in the air similar to if he murdered his wife or not.  All we know is that just going off the movie title "once upon a time" we can tell that this movie will contain a lot of fictional depictions of the era and the people. Moving on to Margot Robbies portrayal of sharon tate, it was simply genius as she was able to convey Tate's overall personality with few lines just pure expression. Her act left me not wanting anymore than I have recieved as her purpose was also not to be a deep delved in biographical portrayal but a great stand in to represent the late sharon tate. The cinematography was great obviously focusing on the the aesthetic of the time with great attention to detail from the lesser known dirty movie theater to the o so timeless classic cars which were a joy to see on screen. Let us not forget about the great tarentino touch of violence in his movies arguably being some of the most fun and entertaining deaths I have ever see on the big screen, I mean you have spoiler alert a manson girl who dies from being pelted by a dog food can and another one being flamethrowered. And the cherry ontop the most cringeworthy attack of all being bit in the nuts by a giant dog. Definitely a 10/10 movie, a must watch for fans and those who seek movies such as this, get it on blue ray easily an entertaining rewatchable movie.

The critics and audience ratings are ridiculous, the movie was a total waste of my wife's and my time. We were dragged through minute by minute waiting for a significant story line to appear, and wouldn't you know after 160 minutes of waiting for something to happen the Manson family go to the wrong house and are themselves killed, (at this point you would need to know the factual truth about this incident) . The reason I say the wrong house is because in 1969 they didn't go to the the wrong house and they weren't killed, they in fact brutally murdered pregnant Sharon Tate and her house guests, not to original Quentin. I think that Mr. Tarantino actually smoked the acid laced cigarette before he wrote this garbage.
This movie couldn't hold a candle to the Beverly Hillbillies, what happened to movies like Key Largo, The Maltese Falcon, The Godfather, Hunt for Red October, Tombstone, The Outlaw Josey Wales, Goodfellas, just to name a few. I truly don't understand how people can find movies of this caliber remotely entertaining. Both my wife and I are 61 and know good from bad when it comes to cinema and this was a pure waste of valuable time, actually the music score was very good but I would have preferred to watch 3 episodes of The Rockford Files instead. I could go on and on about the garbage Hollywood critics and the general public find entertaining these days, but I just wasted 160 minutes of my life and must remember not to ever watch another Tarantino movie. Somebody please produce something worthwhile before I die.

Sharon Tate's sister said it best: "When you put the names Tarantino and Manson together, this is not what you'd expect." Those hellbent on seeing a traditionally violent Tarantino movie might be disappointed; those who love history, film history, and experimental style in cinema will be very satisfied. The Rotten Tomatoes critic consensus calls this "thrillingly unrestrained" but I don't think that's accurate. This is the most restrained, and arguably the most deliberate and poised that Tarantino's ever been; from the opening shot you know you are in the hands of a master of his craft. This IS a traditional Tarantino movie, with elements of many of his all time classics - multiple plot lines, an abundance of references, metaphorical violence, seamless flashbacks that are the closest cinematic equivalent to Leopold Bloom's wandering thoughts in Ulysses that we have - but it moves slower, you have to pay closer attention, and the moments of cartoonish bloodshed are scarcer yet arguably sharper. I haven't seen a better movie in 2019.

This film is going to age like fine wine (or Brad Pitt). I'll call it now, in a decade this will have the top QT status amongst Reservoir Dogs and Pulp Fiction. His 9th outing is an effortlessly immersive and truly entertaining time machine to the 60's, with more feet than ever before. We witness some of the best written characters of the year alter history, make spaghetti-westerns, feed their dog, burn hippies and watch TV. We reflect as a former television star struggles to keep up in an ever-changing world. And we do enjoy seeing Pitt smash a hippie into an art-deco mantelpiece. Red Apple cigarettes of an abundance, Tarantino lets his characters drive the story, creating a more comfortable atmosphere than he has previously.  
Sharon Tate (Margot Robbie) watches her own movie (which features the real Sharon Tate), and there is something about seeing her pride as the audience around her enjoy her performance that is much more powerful than a certain (completely poorly executed) film of this same year that attempts to tackle the same subject matter. 
Tarantino's writing is some of his best work. The production design is incredible. The music is a hand-picked selection from the time (sadly a year off being able to rehash 'Little Green Bag'), with the occasional obscure reference to television adverts and forgotten 60's pop culture. 
Then we are thrown out of time, to the tune of 'Out of Time.' Once Upon a Time... In Hollywood is a fairytale tribute to the 60's, cinema, changing times and, most importantly completely rejects the horrific events that don't get the light of day, and are certainly not repulsively taken advantage of (à la The Haunting of Sharon Tate).

It's a wondering epic, delving into the lives of Los Angeles industry folk -- informative and inventive in its treatment of iconic stories and stars -- it's a love letter to what was and what could have been. Each frame stamped with audio and visual markers of the time, the face of 1960s Los Angeles could very well be listed at top of show. We amble around the city's diverse landscapes, move seamlessly from scenes revealing who and what made our our characters who they are, to presentational docu-style VO and montage, to B&W clips from "TV shows" and back and forth and back again. As the city and its inhabitants flit and flaunt, each sign and symbol plays a role, as we slowly progress with a Bresson-like cool elegance. While Once Upon A Time creeps and lulls, time seems to slow, and the anxiety of the approach fills the void. At some point extreme violence will be unleashed, but it's a careful cat and mouse on the biggest and most dynamic of stages -- something only someone like Tarantino, professionally and personally, could create. The story, largely centered on the fall of Dicaprio's stumbling and fumbling aging star, weighs proportionately with the up-swing of Sharon Tate and her buoyant untouchables, while Pitt's cool and ageless form drives steady on like Los Angeles itself. 

It's a finely composed masterful piece: specific, unique, intentional. Tarantino, like Bresson, made films his own way: "his interior view of cinema had no application if modified," and for that we can be grateful.

I was in college in the 60s. Spent a lot of time in SF, Joan Baez, the Fillmore West and Golden Gate Park/Haight Ashbury.  Had come from the Vietnam War.  There were no cell phones or computers. We actually LIVED our lives in groups, big protests every day blocking streets, sit-ins at colleges.  Going to jail was EXPECTED.

CIVIL rights, freedom riders, the killing of JFK in '63 then MLK jr and Bobby Kennedy in ‘68.  The entire nation mourned...it wasn't just in the news for one day...then gone. We GRIEVED for weeks.  No cable TV...but then I had no TV.  No one had the money.  At 18, you left home. No money from parents, just working basic jobs: nurse aide in ICU, maid at TraveLodges, waitress at Holiday Inn. Had a scholarship, so was able to go to school.  Jean-Claude Killy was triple gold champ in skiing and we skiers worshipped him!  Rossignol Skis, Head 360s, we went from wooden skis and leather boots w long thongs to fiberglass Hart skis and plastic boots.

This is what this movie showed to me.  Things played out through long days on movie sets, real life--living on own with only a dog.  Unless you lived through the time you would NEVER have understood living next door to Roman Polanski and Sharon Tate.  Instead of just being a victim, she was a wonderfully happy blonde actor from Dean Martin and the Wrecking Crew...I loved who she was.  The REAL old TV series like Wanted Alive with Steve McQueen, it was a BIG step up to movies like the Great Escape including carrying that baseball glove and ball.

Spaghetti Westerns turned Clint Eastwood from a TV "oater", a western Round-Up with Rowdy Gaines into a major movie star and director---for Rick Dalton (DiCaprio) Spaghetti Westerns, were a last chance.  Perfect!  The actors all shot their scenes in their own languages and no attempt was made to have all speak English, Spanish, or Italian.  It was chaos.  But we went to those movies like a Fistful of Dollars for Clint Eastwood--steely eyed tall, lanky actor for his cigarillo, Mexican poncho, and quick draw. The three movies lasted 3-4 hours with practically no dialogue, few action sequences that went on for 15-20 minutes each of ppl mainly staring each other down. NO ONE WAS BORED.  Best yet? We watched them at a Drive-Inn---how many ppl under 60 knew what a drive-in was.

Ahh the music was great.  Unless you lived at the time you didn't understand the power of music that everyone knew--even Rick Dalton singing in his floating chair in THE status symbol--a kidney shaped pool.  I was singing along to every song as I had seen every singer in person--not a Youtube video--but in person. Sitting in Golden Gate sitting on the grass listening to Joan Baez, Bob Dylan, Quick Silver Messenger Service. Tickets for Jim Morrison/Doors, Jefferson Airplane were $3! Also weed was everywhere.  I remember having to make money w 10 friends, I drove from Phoenix with a pickup filled with red cellophane kilo bricks of weed.  Threw straw on top, covered with a tarp, wore my western shirt and cowboy hat and drove home.  I was Miss Rodeo Queen and cute (LONNNG time ago) so was never pulled over by the police. We all spent a weekend listening to the Woodstock double vinyl album on HUGE speakers with a record player, separating out the buds from the stems--then putting stems into an Osterizer blender. Nickel and Dime bags that truly were plastic sandwich bags rolled up with rubber bands at $5 and $10 each.  We'd be so STONED because we were always passing around doobies (blunts) and inhaling.

The whole Spahn Ranch was TERRIFYING because everyone knew who Charlie Manson and Squeaky Fromme were!  The Manson Family. From their "Helter Skelter blood stains and wall writings at the slaughter of Sharon Tate et al, to the attempted assassination of Reagan.  Except Manson was really small. Showing Tate pregnant and her new nursery was awful!  Because the Manson Family WOULD slaughter her when she was pregnant. Interesting that all the girls/women called him Charlie and NO ONE said Manson.  I was VERY glad that they didn't show the slaughter.  But the story of Rick Dalton ending a good career making cigarette ads (Loved how he threw the cigarette Red Apple on the floor in disgust and tore down his cutout picture!)  He was the epitome of the end of radio, three primetime news stations, and the old by the book TV shows like Mannix, and the number of TV and Movie Westerns.

Brad Pitt as the stunt man?  Wow--never really thought of those guys and how they were also go-fers for the star.  He was magnificent--not too bright (as was Rick Dalton.)  Loved how he went after Bruce Lee. Lee brought karate and Kung Foo fighting to mainstream TV.  What a DICK!

Thank you Quentin Tarantino for a PERFECT movie of that time!

Really liked the movie!!! You can't go wrong with Tarantino. And Leo and Brad are always a joy to watch in action. It's a really cool telling of an alternate reality of a tragic event in Hollywood. The casting, plot, and dialogue were great!

To watch a Tarantino for over 90 minutes before anything happens like a murder is torture. I think although a tale well told he got lost on his own bs and romance with this story...the end could have shown two scenarios or something but what he did left zero intrigue...honestly disappointed

The promotion for this movie was misleading and designed to get people to watch it who would never have chosen to in the first place. Bottom line, it is a vanity project designed to appeal to those who live and breathe everything Hollywood and who revel in all its disfunctionality and self-absorption. Virtually nothing redeemable about it.

The actors are solid, and it's entertaining, but not a masterful work of art. And I have mixed feelings about altering the real life terrible ending to the story with a much happier one.

i wish that Tex was chewed up by a dog in real life but how dare he use that evil event for his little fantasy. Flippant tripe, totally despise it.

Review: 
‘Once Upon a Time in Hollywood' is a comedy-drama film directed by Quentin Tarantino.
From when this movie first started, I knew I was in for another masterpiece from one of the greatest filmmakers alive.  Tarantino is one of those directors that you love him or hate him, and most of movie lovers choose the ladder.
Set in 1969 Los Angeles, the film follows an actor (Leonardo DiCaprio) and his stunt double (Brad Pitt), as they navigate the changing film industry, and features multiple storylines in a modern fairy tale tribute to the final moments of Hollywood's golden age.
We all know the actors in any Tarantino movie brings their A-game. We just haven't seen anybody act the way they do in this movie. Leonardo DiCaprio was great as an actor on the brinks of being a has been and struggling to keep up with the greats. My personal favorite is Brad Pritt as DiCaprio's stunt man. He was so funny and when he was needed to be serious, he brought it!
This movie was perfection to me! Everything plays a part in the experience. This is some of the best acting I have seen in a long time. I was swept away with the look, music, and story. The best part of this movie is when you are spending time with these characters. One of my favorite scenes is when Brad Pitt and Leonardo DiCaprio are sitting on the couch watching a screening of DiCaprio's shows and doing commentary on it. It was great.
Overall, this movie was a high anticipation of mine and it did not disappoint. It has great performances and tells a high stakes story that keeps you on the edge of your seat.
5/5
Just....WOW. Great Tribute to the 60's by Tarantino.

Quentin Tarantino was back in 2019 with his most self-indulgent, yet entertaining, yarn since "Jackie Brown" (1997). Actually, the Tarantino film most comparable to "Once Upon a Time ... in Hollywood," his fictionalization of the Sharon Tate story, is clearly "Inglourious Basterds" (2009), and in truth I would have liked this movie far more had its gimmick not already been deployed 10 years ago. But that aside, "Once Upon a Time ... in Hollywood" offers Leonardo DiCaprio and Brad Pitt A-plus parts and ample opportunity to act their hearts out with old-fashioned swagger, especially in a classic scene between DiCaprio and Julia Butters, playing a precocious child actor. Speaking of which, fanboy Tarantino's embrace and re-creation and in some cases brazen fabrication of '50s and '60s westerns, actors, TV shows and even products (rat-flavored dog food!) are giddily on display every minute of the film, making it a Hollywood film about Hollywood that any like-minded film buff would enjoy. Margot Robbie's casting as Sharon Tate (who you may have heard died in 1968) initially seemed off, but she wound up embodying her so beautifully that actual footage of Tate from "The Wrecking Crew" (1968) is used without causing a double-take that the woman watching "herself" in it is an entirely different person.

Once Upon a Time in Hollywood is what you expect it to be. I really enjoy the first 2 hours of this movie. Following an actor and his stuntman living their life is Hollywood is great. This time period is always great especially set in LA. The movie starts to go off the rails in regards to the Manson family. The ending is not expected but not in a good way. Inglorious Bastards is great because of the twist at the end. This movie isn't for everyone but I understand that some may love it. I think it's a good movie but nothing more.
Interesting story from master screenwriter/director Quentin Tarantino. So cool to see the last stages of Old Hollywood.

Revisionist history worked brilliantly in Inglourious Basterds....but not this time. While I didn't mind this movie, I didn't exactly love it either and frankly didn't buy how everything wrapped up. Not one of Tarantino's best in my opinion.

I hate to say it, but I honestly think this is the worst Quentin Tarantino film. There was almost no story or point to it, we just watch Brad, Leo, and Margot "doing things". We follow Leonardo Dicaprio's Rick Dalton as he starts making spaghetti westerns but none of these scenes feel relevant, he's also shown to have a drinking problem, but there's no resolution to that character flaw. Brad Pitt's Cliff Booth keeps having run ins with the Manson family and other people in Hollywood that don't really like him. They try to cram in some backstory about him possibly killing his wife, but again, this doesn't really matter. The Bruce Lee scene was totally random and Charles Manson was only in one small scene. We also watch Sharon Tate while she watches her own movie... for most of this movie. The end fight scene was pretty interesting but came way too late. I really don't understand what story Quentin Tarantino was trying to tell with this.

There was little focus on the point of the film.  Way too long and slow moving. Zig -zagged throughout from past and present and it was tough to stay interested.  I watched it because of Leo and Brad but not worth the viewing. Never blossom into anything a good story line should be.

Thoroughly enjoyed the flick but understand that many will find the movie slow and fail to appreciate the attention to detail in character development and dark humor aspects. The ending was spectacular and unexpected.

Tremendous acting supplements the 60s Hollywood theme of OUATIH, which was one of the most enjoyable films of the year for me. The ending is stupendously satisfying in a breathtaking and violent bang that couldn't be better.

Interesting how Steve McQueen was a celebrity in it and was portrayed respectfully, but Bruce Lee, who fought his whole life against discrimination admirably, was so disgustingly turned unto a caricature. Im sick of QT conveniently making movies in the past as an excuse to use every racial slur or discriminatory behaviour he can. Ironically, I was a huge QT fan with Kill Bill vol 1 and Pulp Fiction being two favorites. But unfortunately this is what he's become now. Even the women are used as props for men's ego. Sharon Tate dances around looking pretty, propping her feet up instead of talking. Under age Pussycat boorishly throws herself at Brad Pitt most of it, making him seem desirable and cool. Even the poor little girl actor only serves to make DiCaprio feel better about himself. Besides glaringly offensive content, its a boring film otherwise, with only nuggets of excitement.

This is generally only a film for Hollywood geeks. It is mainly style over substance, full of unrealistic imagery from a fake made-up world of 1960s American trash. The character development of the female characters in particular is virtually non-existent, with the Sharon Tate character presented as little more than a dancing sex object (complete with lingering shots of her legs) and the young hippy girl, who appears to be a child, being depicted as a highly sexed object (called ‘Pussycat') who is subject to a needless and prolonged shot of her backside. This shallow depiction of girls and women may play into the director's juvenile fantasies but it is not a realistic view of human beings and is unoriginal and tiresome. Generally the film drags along as a kind of homage to the director's fantasy of what film production in Hollywood in the 1960s would have been like, but it's a fantasy that is unlikely to engage the interest of many viewers. There are some comedic and poignant moments and the last 20 minutes of revenge violence is satisfying, but overall you're better off not wasting your time on this film- and given that the film is nearly 3 hours long, it is a lot of time that you will be wasting.
The whole movie was a complete disappointment.

There are many individual moments in this film that I loved, but many times when I looked at the clock and wondered just where Tarantino was going with the movie as it meandered from scene to scene, especially in the first half. The main characters, who I expected not to care about at all, grew on me as the film progressed, which is a testament to Tarantino's skill and strong performances by Brad Pitt and Leonardo di Caprio. The greatest part of the film is the final act. A sense of horrible tension grows, as I as viewer expect to see an enactment of the brutal Manson Family murders. Instead, Tarantino gives us an alternate history in which several Manson cultists are, what I can only describe as, Tarantino-ed to death with farcical levels of brutality - witch are strangely cathartic compared to the pitiful true life horror I expected to have to endure watching. The ending also explains the "Once Upon a Time..." title, as we're reminded of the tragedy that actually took place that night.
In my opinion one of his greatest films.

I don't like a lot of fiction but because so much of it was based on true events and real people, this changed my view.  If you don't appreciate Tarantino's thought process, you won't like it.  In fact, I had no plans to see this movie until I saw the Vanity Fair interview with Quentin and Leo.   I have already watched this movie 3 times since I first saw it last Sunday.  If you liked American Psycho, I think you will like this movie.   American Psycho being my favorite and only other fiction movie I will continue to praise.  Two totally different stories but you can feel the passion in both and where the writers /directors are coming from.   Wasn't too long for me.  In fact, I wish it didn't end where it did.   Brad and Leo were phenomenal and I felt as if I knew "Rick and Cliff"  because of their chemistry and superb acting.  Bottom line, you either love this movie or don't get it.   For me, this is second favorite movie of all time!

The movies was well acted, one of DiCaprio's best performance. However that's all the good things I can say. It's not a terrible film, it just amounts to nothing. There's a lot of build up especially to that faithful night of 1969, but it amounted to nothing. There was a lot of thing that happened in the beginning and during the film that could have come as cause and consequence but led to nothing. Margot Robbies role as Sharon Tate amounted to nothing. Sharon Tate could have been played by anyone and she didn't have that moment in the film that made her stand out. Uma in Pulp Fiction had a small part, but it was a memorable one. Pam Grier captured each scene in Jackie Brown. I felt Robbie was given nothing to make her stand out. Also I HATED how he portrayed Bruce Lee in this film. Yet he kept saying that's how he was in real life yet those who actually knew and worked with him say otherwise. All in all not a terrible film, but not worth your time. If you haven't seen it you can skip it, you're not missing much.

This is a hard film to review. I liked it, my grandfather did not. Great performances, direction and cinematography, but one has to wonder what was the point of all this? It seems to me that this film is nothing more than a love letter to a bygone era of Hollywood. The people, the cars, the culture and whatnot. Also Tarantino decided to take a sensitive topic of Sharon Stone which was risky to say the least. I am still glad to say that the risk paid off and it's a quite enjoyable film. Just not enjoyable as I expected. The last half-an-hour or so falls short of making up more than two hours that followed behind it. An one-time watch for me at least.

A touching tribute to Hollywood in the late 1960s. Fun from start to finish.

When this was initially released, my gut instincts told me not to waste my time. However, with all of the awards buzz it's been receiving, I decided to give it a look on DVD, after which I realized my initial reaction was right: Absolute utter garbage, overrated in virtually every respect (except, perhaps, for Leonardo DiCaprio's fine lead performance). What praise is there to be given for two dragged-out hours of boring, tedious, mundane activity, followed by a gratuitously grotesque conclusion that's supposed to be...funny? My only takeaway from this is that Quentin Tarantino may be a master of nostalgia in his authentic re-creation of past pop culture but little else, which, frankly, makes me wonder, "who cares?" The director has hinted that his next picture will be his last; let's hope he keeps his word.
Tarantino says the characters are enough to drive the film and that a storyline was unnecessary because the characters are so interesting, but I strongly disagree.

In my opinion it wasn't a very good film. I expected a lot more from Tarantino, it didn't really fit his regularly scheme of movie making the gore and the profanity was lacking throughout. But it was an ok film. If it was made by an unknown director I probably would have rated it higher, but I was hyped for this film and was overall disappointed.

Once Upon a Time in Hollywood –OUATIH para los amigos– es una película que funciona como una memoria de Hollywood en 1969, pero vista desde la subjetividad de Tarantino. Desde sus ojos, oídos y mente que idealizan una época y le rinden el más grande homenaje de todos al tomar su momento más crucial –la muerte de Sharon Tate en manos de la familia Manson– y lo convierten en un cuento de hadas. 

Porque OUATIH es muchas cosas, pero en base es eso: un cuento de hadas que narra un día en la vida de tres personajes –en realidad, un día y una noche– de los que Tarantino se vale para que entendamos cuál es el Hollywood que él recuerda, que él ama, que él todavía vive.

Al menos de eso se tratan las primeras dos de las casi tres horas de este filme, en las que vemos al personaje de Leonardo  DiCaprio trabajando, al de Brad Pitt manejando y coqueteando con hippies y al de Margot Robbie –Sharon Tate en la película– yendo al cine, todos sumergidos en una avalancha de referencias destinadas a despertar memorias en los más viejos y poner en contexto a los más jóvenes. 

Este fue Hollywood, nos dice Tarantino. Así sonaba, esto pasaba, esta es la música que se escuchaba, las drogas que se tomaban, esto era ir al cine antes de las salas de cine, así funcionaba la industria para los actores y los dobles de riesgo, así trabajaban los representantes y así vivían los grandes directores, o los actores populares y hasta los olvidados. Estas eran sus fiestas y estas sus rutinas, estos eran sus miedos y sus gajes, estas eran las personas que vivieron los días de 1969, antes de que Manson y sus seguidores lo cambiaran todo. 

Porque eso hicieron: cambiaron la historia. El asesinato de Sharon Tate marcó el fin del jipismo –cuyo panegírico fue Woodstock– pero también trajo un cambio importante en la cultura popular y psicología de todo un país. Del mundo, en realidad, porque Hollywood significa mainstream y ya desde entonces los yanquis exportaban cultura. Y por eso estas dos horas del onanismo nostálgico de Tarantino son importantes. Porque en ellas –a través de la nostalgia de Quentin, estoy hablando de la música en la radio, las calles y sus carteles encendiéndose por la noche, las voces de los locutores de radio, los programas en la televisión– se construye un ambiente que en los últimos minutos –en la usual clave de violencia tarantinesca– deconstruye la nostalgia para que los 20 segundos finales transformen al filme en un cuento de hadas. 

Y todo a partir de una pregunta muy sencilla: ¿cómo habría sido el mundo si las cosas hubieran sido diferentes?

Por eso, cuando dicen que es muy lenta, que es muy larga, que podía ser más corta y permanecer poderosa, me pregunto: ¿cómo es posible que esperemos años por películas de Marvel, o temporadas de Game of Thrones, pero no seamos capaces de disfrutar dos horas de construcción de trama y ambiente? ¿De qué manera, entonces, podremos entender cómo un actor acabado, narcisista e inseguro y un doble de riesgo con un pasado reprobable pueden ser héroes y cambiar la historia? ¿Cómo habría sido el presente si los recordáramos a ellos y no a Manson?

De alguna forma Quentin hizo lo mismo que hace siempre, pero le dio un muy necesario giro de frescura. Este filme lo marca como más dispuesto a jugar con el lenguaje visual, esta vez a su manera. Ya no son solo homenajes divertidos que dan tono, ahora tienen la meta de dar tono y profundizar el giro de la trama.

 Eso se nota en algo tan sencillo como que el lenguaje de las cámaras, en las primeras horas del filme, es típico del western clásico, para darse el gusto de mostrarse como un muy sobrio spaghetti western en los últimos minutos. No es que haya algo nuevo bajo el sol en las tierras de Quentin Tarantino, es que los años lo han animado a ser un poco más sutil, íntimo y honesto.

¡Y el elenco! ¡Qué buenas actuaciones! Primero que nada, DiCaprio que encarna con maestría a un actor derrotado –lo cual, cuando eres un actor de la calidad de DiCaprio, debe ser más que difícil–. También está Margot Robbie que enternece en su rol de Sharon Tate y la representa tal como la describieron las leyendas tras su muerte: un ser alegre, tan humano como angelical, cuya misión es ganarse la ternura del público, tal como lo hizo la Tate original. 

Pero el que se roba la película es Brad Pitt con el personaje más misterioso y mejor construido de todos, un vaquero de la vida real, un sujeto posiblemente horrible, pero al que conocemos desde su lado más tierno, un protagónico que comparte escenas con los mejores personajes secundarios: Margareth Qualley en su encarnación del horror oculto en el cuerpo de la juventud y Brandy, la pitbull –verdadera heroína de la película– que hace de su fiel mascota en un guiño muy tarantinesco: un doble de acción dueño de una can tan entrenada como tuvo que estarlo Lassie.

En resumen: es el Tarantino de siempre, pero se siente más íntimo, maduro. Es un Tarantino que se da el trabajo de, lentamente, ponernos en contexto para compartir con nosotros un recuerdo muy suyo. Y, lo mejor, no está solo, cuenta con un impresionante elenco que le puso alma, vida y corazón a una película sencilla en apariencia, pero que de seguro requirió de muchísimo trabajo. Así que hay que verla. Sí o sí en cine, sí o sí en su idioma original.

Once Upon a Time in Hollywood is what you expect it to be. I really enjoy the first 2 hours of this movie. Following an actor and his stuntman living their life is Hollywood is great. This time period is always great especially set in LA. The movie starts to go off the rails in regards to the Manson family. The ending is not expected but not in a good way. Inglorious Bastards is great because of the twist at the end. This movie isn't for everyone but I understand that some may love it. I think it's a good movie but nothing more.

The rewarding plot twist at the end justifies the slow buildup. Everything was on point, and DiCaprio and Pitt are an amazing duo. Tarantino at his absolute best.

At least it's original. In a year where Disney made 80% off the top box office hits on remakes and sequels, it's just good to see something different for a change. While Tarantino's tenth film is unique in its vision and storytelling, Once Upon a Time In Hollywood is weird and boring. Getting to see so much talent on screen was nice but not in an unenjoyable bonkers fairy tale uselessly set in a real time in history with real people without telling the real events. Perhaps if the rumors are true it is better for this to be Tarantino's final feature especially if he's going to continue being racist and misogynistic.
Honestly, it was a bit boring.

Pointless parading around famous actors without any rhyme or reason. Terrible

Definitely a movie by Tarantino, for Tarantino. Leo was exceptional and Pitt was fantastic. I could re-watch Leo yelling at hippies in his robe, blender of frozen margarita in hand, on repeat. The casting looks-wise was spot-on and there was not a single weak link in the acting. Many lovely cameos too (Pacino, Damian Lewis, Kurt Russel, Lena Dunham, etc.). A story of "old" Hollywood meeting the new on the days leading up to the literal and figurative end of the 1960s and what it stood for. Surprisingly, only a handful of violent scenes — but they dialed up the gore to make up for quality what they lacked in quantity. The alternate history ending was cathartic for what is was, and depressing because it had not been. Oh, and don't overlook the flamethrower…
Excellent Film. Tarantino never misses.
